Hopefully the switch on this new model isn't prone to the same problem.

  49. I've only had this unit less than a week. I had the previous model (100) for several years.<br /><br />Here are the things I like better about this model:<br /><br />1. Switch on handle. The button on the old model would get stuck all the time. On the new unit, you have to be careful not to hit the switch that releases the tip...you will have water all over the place. I haven't found the power switch on the handle difficult to operate.<br /><br />2. I like the way the reservoir is situated on this model. Easier to remove and fill with water. I don't care about the tip storage. Perhaps that's more important for a family. I'm the only one who uses this unit. The reservoir cover also had slots so perhaps it will air it out better.<br /><br />3. I like the handle holder better on this one. The old one would crack.<br /><br />4. I like the new, streamlined look.<br /><br />Since I've only had it for a while I can't vouch for any reliability or mechanical issues yet. With my last Waterpik the company was very responsive when it came to sending out replacement units and parts when I had a problem.

  52. For those of you unfamiliar with this device, it is an electric toothbrush, which takes the following approach to teeth cleaning. Spray a fluid with pulsing and high velocity, and it should clean as well as or better than a conventional toothbrush and floss. I recently lost a crown, possibly due in part because of a tight space between the crown and the neighboring tooth. My dentist enthusiastically recommend this device, and claimed that there are studies who claim that use of this device is as good or better than conventional brushing and flossing. After spending so much $ on reparative work, for this price, let me try it out. I am desperate. OK, not perfect. Use once for 5 minutes per 2 hours. Sprays about. Still learning how to use it. How will it hold up over time? How well will I keep the reservoir and device clean? For now, it seems to work well. It seems to clean well. I warm up water for reservoir in a microwave container in a microwave oven. My initial impression: If it holds up, until someone engineers a better / stronger device, it seems to do what it is expected to do, and I perceive that this a better than what I had been using for my dental hygiene. And the cost of the device is IMO quite reasonable (w 3Y warranty).
  53. Great product, especially after getting a replacement from the first one that leaked water when it was on. Contacted amazon and got a new one the next day!

If I find out that I'm missing something obvious I'll go back and make this 4 or 5 stars, but this is a very agitating design flaw from what I can tell.
  85. The Waterpik works great. It's a great flosser and recommended by my dental hygienist. It sets up easily, and can be started to work in a minute or two. The only downside I find is that the water tank doesn't last as long as I like it to, but then again, I use it at practically full blast and like to floss to the point that I am sure I get every little spot.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Easy to set up<br />- Straight forward to use<br />- Customizable power.<br />- Easy to refill tank<br />- Relatively easy to keep clean<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Doesn't disassemble well to clean (Water feels trapped in there and difficult to get out, worries me about cleanliness later on)<br />- Water tank doesn't reserve as much water as I like it to, and you pretty much have to stop everything to refill the tank then start up again<br />- Wires can easily get tangled up if you have to put it away every time you use it.
  86. This is a very useful device especially for people like me who has dental work.<br />I have dental crown fitted and often food particle stuck around it, I tried to extract those food particles with string floss but many a times in vain without any success or actual removal of the stuck particles, which then in couple of days culminates to gum swelling, pain and bleeding. Also sometimes I worry using string floss as dailly pulling and pushing forces against the dental work may actually damage the crown work in long run.<br />Then bought this product and it worked great for me by saving my dentist visit and paying off almost the investment I made in this product on very first use.<br />The default tips that come with this product is generally enough for single person user. that too mostly I use jet tip(Not the ultra pik). If any other family member is planning to use this machine then you should order extra jet tips(In-case you don't want to share your original jet tip with others).<br />I did ordered ultra pik tip but I think I over invested in those. As they eject very fine water pressure jet. and I don't think anybody will ever use these in family including myself.<br />I use it at the setting of 4-5... any thing above 6 is too much water jet pressure for gum to manage in long run.<br />I surely recommend these product to anybody who has dental work like crown/bridge/braces done to there teeths. This is a must have for your tooth and gum care for your family.

Who knows.<br /><br />I hate flossing. It takes forever, it tastes like fingers and blood, and my worst teeth for tartar deposits are also my hardest teeth to reach with fingers and string.<br /><br />I wanted to address the issue without making myself totally miserable, and thus I did some research into floss alternatives. I ended up buying the Waterpik Aquarius, and I use it twice a day. I haven't been to the dentist yet, but I'm going to be shocked if he doesn't pat me on the head for improving my home care. My teeth sure feel cleaner, and the process of using the thing is exponentially less miserable and at least an order of magnitude faster than using string floss. Plus I don't have piles of bloody string laying around in the trash can for the dogs to knock over and drag everywhere. Win win.

  147. ORIGINAL REVIEW Dec. 29, 2014<br /><br />This is day one with my new Waterpik Aquarius (bought with some Christmas money from a \\"Daily Deal\\" listing on Amazon). So far, I've tried it twice, and I'll use it again before bed. This is mostly to practice the technique, but maybe also a bit because it's kind of fun to use. Most importantly, however, it does appear to work as advertised.<br /><br />If you're new to this device like I am, remember to start at the lowest pressure setting and work up from there. Find the highest comfortable setting and use that. If it hurts, stop and turn the thing down a bit. And use WARM water.<br /><br />I'm glad I got this Waterpik. I already use a Sonicare brush, so this is a nice addition.<br /><br />UPDATE Jan. 15, 2015<br />Waterpik guarantees results within two weeks, so I kept that in mind and decided I'd comment on it here. It might not matter now that there are so many more reviews. Nobody may ever see this one, hehe.   181. The Waterpik Aquarius WP-660 is a great product. I read all the reviews on Amazon before purchasing, and even purchased the older model for my daughter so that I could compare the two. I like the Aquarius over the older model because it is smaller. The lid is attached to the frame so you can pop it back and take out the bowl. On the older version the lid is not attached, so you must remove both the bowl and lid to fill it. The older version also holds more fluid and takes up more space and is just a bit heavier. Some complained about the pick holder being smaller and harder to manage on this newer model, I find nothing wrong with it. They are both noisy and I don't know why with today's technology that could not have been fixed. I started using it on level 2 and now I am up to level 6. I also add Listerine with Alcohol and have not had any problems.
  182. I could not believe how much residue was washed out of my teeth!
  183. I should probably give this device five stars, but just can't make myself do it, only because the little thing is so light and cheap feeling, (Design tip: Maybe instead of being tall, it should be wide.) the little curly spring-like hose pulls on the unit, and I've had it tip over. The only setting I use is max, but that's just me, (I'm a pretty big, 50 yr old man.) all the lower settings are so low, they're pretty useless. (Keeping in mind they're probably good for kids on those lower settings.) Comes with a couple toothbrush like heads, but they're so small and dainty, again, worthless for an adult, but maybe good for cleaning kids, or maybe baby teeth, I would like to see a real manly toothbrush included, one that feels substantial; overall, this thing is okay, but feels a little bit like a cheap plastic kids toy to me; but I use it regularly, and I guess I like it overall. I looked hard all over the Internet, and couldn't find anything I thought I would like better.<br /><br />I would like to see them come out with a model designed and marketed just for big old guys like me. A big, heavy, (wide, not tall) high pressure unit, with a long-flexible hose, and big solid very manly toothbrushes, I'd pay extra for something designed like that just for me. (Put a warning on it, that says, &#34;Not for kids! Adults only!&#34; And actually mean it!) This device seems to be trying to accommodate children and adults in the same unit, and it just falls short to master either...well, I take that back, this is a probably a pretty good little unit for kids...if they can keep from knocking it over.<br /><br />Overall, I would say this is a kids device, that tries to accommodate adults; leaves me wishing for something better though.

  235. I love this product!<br />I have teeth that are very close together and flossing has always been difficult for me. My mouth feels so clean afterwards it is way better than flossing.   242. This is great- I had no idea that water flossers existed until recently and I couldn't be happier with this purchase. This product is definitely worth purchasing.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1.) Regular flossing takes so much more time and this machine saves at least 2 minutes everyday compared to regular flossing, or about 12 hours a year.<br />2.) I feel water flossing gets between the gums much better than normal flossing<br />3.) Think about how much money you save on dental bills. Most people don't floss normally because its a pain in the ass, but this makes the process so much easier, which helps keep your gums healthy<br /><br />Cons:<br />1.) Works well near the gum-line but harder to use between teeth if you have tight spaces, especially around the molars.<br />2.) kind of loud, can be heard through the wall if someone is sleeping<br />3.) somewhat messy in the beginning (water splashes until you get used to moving it around)<br /><br />Conclusion: Worth the ~50 bucks, especially if you're lazy like me and would not otherwise get around to daily flossing the normal way

  279. I have a bias against this tool, because it is a baldface ripoff of my grandfather's invention of the oral irrigator. Dr. C.D. Matteson conceived, invented, patented and produced by hand the original prototype in 1953 in Ft Collins, CO. When I lived as a child in Arlington, VA, he came to visit and spent most of the visit getting the patent done. In 1955-56, when I lived in Ft Collins, my brother and I demonstrated the oral irrigator for his colleagues. On of his &#34;friends&#34; was Mr. Mattingly. He was impressed with it and wanted to partner up with my grandfather to manufacture it. That did not go well. My grandfather's invention was directly screwed on the faucet, had no motor of any type nor electricity and provided a continuous 90 lbs of pressure flow. The valve had the ability to direct the flow to the syringe or directly from the faucet by use of a turnable knob. Mattingly did some work arounds to add a motorized pump and a pulsating flow, neither of which is desirable. So, by purchasing this fraud, I feel as though I am a traitor to my grandfather's vision, but my valve that he invented does not fit on my faucet, so I purchased this instead. It is better than nothing.

  282. I disagree with prior posters who thought the quality was decreased. This is by far the best Waterpik I have used and I have been using them for 16 years. The set up is improved. The stopper has been redesigned and that was always a problem on the older models that used a black rubber stopper that would begin to leak after a year or so.<br />I (and my dentist) credit this product for saving my teeth. I had diseased gums when it was first recommended, now my gums never bleed, even when getting a cleaning at the dentist.<br /><br />This is the only product that removes germs below the gum line. I recommend this product highly.<br />Let me add if I only brush my teeth, I still feel like my teeth are dirty. I also use this product as a \\"tooth pic\\" when I get something stuck between my teeth.   317. ASTONISHING (to me, anyway) HEALTH UPDATE (2/19/2017): WATERPIKING SAVES LIVES, MAYBE YOURS! REALLY! I MEAN IT! (I know, it sounds crazy...)<br /><br />I finally broke down and got a Waterpik when my dentist told me I had periodontal pockets and would need a deep cleaning. I read somewhere that with regular use of a Waterpik, I might just be able to reverse those pockets and eliminate that need for an uncomfortable deep cleaning. I gave it a three-month try and it worked! No deep cleaning needed!<br /><br />Also, I spoke with my primary care physician about plaque, and learned that there are two more (one of them could save your life) benefits to Waterpiking regularly. See my UPDATE at the end of this review.<br /><br />I have noticed that others have asked a lot of the questions that I had early on inside of their reviews and in the customer questions section. So I thought I would gather up all of the answers and put them in one review. I hope this will be your Guide to Using Your New Aquarius Waterpik.<br /><br />If you do find this review helpful, please click &#34;Yes&#34; below, I'd appreciate it!<br /><br />HOW DO I AVOID MAKING MY GUMS BLEED WHEN I START USING MY WATERPIK?<br /><br />It is not in the instructions anymore, but according to my husband, Waterpik used always to tell users to start by using the lowest &#34;1&#34; pressure setting and then to turn the pressure up one notch per day to get your gums adjusted to the Waterpik's pressure gradually. If you do this, you should be on &#34;10&#34;, or whatever setting you prefer, in no time and with no gum bleeding.<br /><br />HOW DO I KEEP FROM SPLASHING WATER EVERYWHERE?<br /><br />There are two simple tricks never to see a water splash again. First, don't turn the Waterpik on until it is in your mouth. Second, keep your mouth closed except a slight parting of your lips to allow water to drain out of your mouth, while you use your Waterpik. That should take care of it!<br /><br />THE ON/OFF SWITCH ON THE HANDLE IS HARD TO USE.<br /><br />You will, unfortunately, just have to get the hang of how to master that switch. It seems to be a matter to where you apply pressure on the switch. It seems to work best when you apply pressure close to the center, rather than from the bottom or the top, in my limited experience. However, in the meantime, if you get frustrated, just use the on/off button on the face of the machine as a shortcut.<br /><br />WHY DO THEY SEND SEVEN TIPS BUT ONLY PROVIDE SLOTS FOR TWO?<br /><br />First of all, you only receive four different types of tips. The total number of tips adds up to seven because Waterpik provides three identical Classic Jet Tips (see below for descriptions of each). Most people choose only one style of tip for daily use (possibly two if you have periodontal pockets). The second slot can also be used for a partner or house-guest.<br /><br />WHAT IS THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN THE FOUR STYLES OF TIPS INCLUDED?<br /><br />&#34;CLASSIC JET TIP&#34; (you get 3)<br />To identify it: it is the only tip style that you get three of.<br />Classic Jet Tips are for general use and replace flossing for people without crowns or other more-serious-than-fillings dental work. (For people with that sort of dental work, use the &#34;Plaque Seeker Tip&#34;, described below.) Use the Classic Jet Tip unless you have a special reason to choose one of the others.<br />Rather than include links to the replacement tips in this review, I recommend that you just do a search for &#34;Waterpik JT-100E&#34;. That way, there's no risk that this review will be filled with dead links.<br /><br />If you search by the tip's name, you will probably get results that include tips that are not compatible with your Aquarius. So I have provided the actual model numbers of each tip so that you can search for the right one. If any tip that you want is not available on Amazon, you can buy it directly from Waterpik dot com. (Note For Ultra Buyers: the Ultra uses the same modeltips as the Aquarius, provided here.)<br /><br />&#34;TOOTHBRUSH TIP&#34; (quantity: 1, but that is plenty for most)<br />To identify it: it looks like a tiny toothbrush.<br />This tip allows you to brush your teeth and Waterpik at the same time. As efficient as that sounds, there must be a reason why they included 3 Classic Jet Tips and only 1 Toothbrush Tip. I am guessing the reason is that this Brush Tip looks more efficient than it is -- especially if you have an effective toothbrush like a Sonicare.<br />Search for &#34;Waterpik TB-100E&#34; to find compatible replacement tips.<br /><br />&#34;PLAQUE SEEKER TIP&#34; (quantity: 1) (my daily use tip)<br />To identify it: look for fewer bristles than are on the Toothbrush Tip.<br />The Plaque Seeker Tip is designed for use with crown, implants, and bridges, as well as for general use. So if you have any dental work more serious than fillings in your mouth (i.e. are you over 30?), you can just use this tip as your daily tip all around your mouth. &#34;Removes bacteria and debris from hard to reach areas around dental restorations.&#34;<br />Search for &#34;Waterpik PS-100E&#34; to buy refills.<br /><br />&#34;PIK POCKET TIP&#34; (quantity: 1)<br />To identify it: it looks like the Classic Jet Tip but with an extra pointy attachment at the end.<br />This one is for people who have periodontal pockets or furcations. It can &#34;deliver medicaments&#34; except that neither the Aquarius nor the Ultra is designed for that (they don't have &#34;Medicament Reservoirs&#34;), or just rinse deep below the gumline. Few people will choose to use the Pik Pocket as their daily tip. You would use this before or after you do your primary Waterpik rinse, and probably just on the areas that need it. This tip is supposed to be used only with the machine set to a pressure of &#34;1&#34;, so don't forget to turn the pressure down before using it.<br />Search for &#34;PP-100E&#34; to get compatible replacement tips.<br /><br />OTHER WATERPIK TIPS YOU CAN BUY ON AMAZON COMPATIBLE WITH THE WATERPIK AQUARIUS: these don't come with your Aquarius but they are compatible with it, and you may find them useful:<br />--Orthodontic tip OD-100E<br />--Tongue Cleaner TC-100E<br /><br />Finally, Waterpik also offers a storage case that comes with six compatible tips. Search for TS-100E.<br /><br />THE WATERPIK AQUARIUS VERUS THE WATERPIK ULTRA: A SHOWDOWN<br /><br />Some reviewers have argued that the older [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Waterpik WP100W Ultra Dental Water Flosser]] is a better device. However, many reviewers have claimed the opposite. Waterpik continues to make both. Here are the differences according to Amazon and Waterpik (you can do comparisons between any current models on Waterpik's website, just type in Waterpik dot com then choose Oral Hygiene):<br /><br />This Model, the Waterpik Aquarius WP-660 is called the &#34;Aquarius Professional&#34; on Waterpik's site. That's cool, right?<br /><br />As of this writing, the Ultra has fewer than 300 reviews that average 4.5 stars; this Aquarius has over 6,000 reviews that average 4.4 stars. Since I don't know if the Ultra's average rating is 4.500000 and the Aquarius's is 4.4999999999, I don't really see any difference in those reviews other than than a LOT more people choose to buy this Aquarius.<br /><br />Differences Between this Aquarius and the [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Ultra]]<br />--while on Amazon, prices vary, Waterpik thinks the Aquarius is the nicer machine because they charge $20 more for the Aquarius than for the Ultra;<br />--the Ultra has a button on the handle that you must hold down in order to keep the water flowing, if you let go, it stops; the Aquarius has an on/off toggle switch so that once you toggle it on, it keeps flowing without finger pressure, until you toggle it off;<br />--the Aquarius comes with three Classic Jet tips, versus two with the Ultra<br />--the Aquarius includes a massage mode (have to admit that I don't use this at all)<br/>--the Aquarius includes an LED Function Indicator (ehh)<br />--the Aquarius includes a Timer/Pacer (I use this every day and know that I would stop sooner than I should if it weren't on there)<br />--the Ultra doesn't include anything that the Aquarius does not<br /><br />Features That Are Identical Between the Aquarius and the Ultra<br />--both come in black and white (Aquarius, this page; [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Waterpik Ultra White and Black available here]];<br />--same water pressure<br />--same flow rate<br />--same pulse rate<br />--both have 10 pressure settings<br />--the tips rotate 360 degrees<br />--water capacity both in volume and in seconds<br />--both have covered water reservoirs<br />--almost identical weight: 1.46 pounds for this Aquarius and 1.48 for the Ultra<br />--both have three-year warranties<br />--both only have plugs for North America<br /><br />SOME OTHER MODELS AVAILABLE:<br /><br />Waterpik Complete Care is still available for $10 more and gives you a shorter warranty (2 years instead of 3), no massage mode, no LED indicators, and fewer tips. Thumbs down.<br /><br />If you're really price sensitive OR if you want to use medicaments OR you really hate filling the reservoir, the Waterpik Classic Pro is $30 less expensive on the Waterpik site (on Amazon, prices vary) includes a medicament reservoir, and holds up to 35 ounces (Aquarius and Ultra hold 22 ounces) but you will not get:<br />--the good reviews that the Aquarius and Ultra have; Classic Pro is not nearly as well-liked;<br />--the option of a black-colored model;<br />--the maximum water pressure of 100 PSI (it's 90 PSI instead)<br />--four pressure settings: you get only six pressure settings instead of ten (but honestly, how many people need the subtlety of more than six settings?);<br />--the super-important-to-me Timer/Pacer<br />--water control on the handle (it works like the Ultra: you have to hold a button down);<br />--a covered reservoir;<br />--covered tip storage;<br />--massage mode;<br />--LED Function Indicator;<br />--the ability to use any tips other than the Classic, the Pik Pocket and the Tongue Cleaner (Waterpik does not make compatible Orthodontic tips, Plaque Seeker tips, or Toothbrush tips for the Waterpik Classic Pro)<br />--the third year of warranty, Classic only comes with a tow-year warranty.<br /><br />I hope this review has been helpful to you. Please feel free to leave comments, as you can see, I have responded to the only question asked, and am happy to answer more. And I'd very much appreciate a &#34;Yes&#34; click if you did find this review at all helpful. (I have dreams of one day qualifying for the VINE reviewer program...)<br /><br />IMPORTANT HEALTH UPDATES (2/19/2017): WATERPIKING SAVES LIVES, MAYBE YOURS!<br /><br />THE LIFESAVING UPDATE: My Primary Care Physician just informed me that PLAQUE in the MOUTH CAUSES PLAQUE in the ARTERIES AND VEINS! !! ! !! That was a big surprise to me. Now I'm REALLY going to use this baby twice a day (like I told my dental hygienist I do &#60;w&#62;).<br /><br />A DENTAL HYGIENE BEST-PRACTICES UPDATE: My Primary also told me that using flossing brushes (like the Pixters my dentist told me to use) actually transfers bacteria from the first tooth to the second, and from the first and second to the third, and so on. Unless of course you use a new one for each tooth, each time. IMHO, they're way too expensive for that! So, she suggested using one per tooth but on a less frequent basis, and using the Waterpik two times, full time, every single day instead.TERPIK TIPS YOU CAN BUY ON AMAZON COMPATIBLE WITH THE WATERPIK AQUARIUS: these don't come with your Aquarius but they are compatible with it, and you may find them useful:<br />--Orthodontic tip OD-100E<br />--Tongue Cleaner TC-100E<br /><br />Finally, Waterpik also offers a storage case that comes with six compatible tips. Search for TS-100E.<br /><br />THE WATERPIK AQUARIUS VERUS THE WATERPIK ULTRA: A SHOWDOWN<br /><br />Some reviewers have argued that the older [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Waterpik WP100W Ultra Dental Water Flosser]] is a better device. However, many reviewers have claimed the opposite. Waterpik continues to make both. Here are the differences according to Amazon and Waterpik (you can do comparisons between any current models on Waterpik's website, just type in Waterpik dot com then choose Oral Hygiene):<br /><br />This Model, the Waterpik Aquarius WP-660 is called the &#34;Aquarius Professional&#34; on Waterpik's site. That's cool, right?<br /><br />As of this writing, the Ultra has fewer than 300 reviews that average 4.5 stars; this Aquarius has over 6,000 reviews that average 4.4 stars. Since I don't know if the Ultra's average rating is 4.500000 and the Aquarius's is 4.4999999999, I don't really see any difference in those reviews other than than a LOT more people choose to buy this Aquarius.<br /><br />Differences Between this Aquarius and the [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Ultra]]<br />--while on Amazon, prices vary, Waterpik thinks the Aquarius is the nicer machine because they charge $20 more for the Aquarius than for the Ultra;<br />--the Ultra has a button on the handle that you must hold down in order to keep the water flowing, if you let go, it stops; the Aquarius has an on/off toggle switch so that once you toggle it on, it keeps flowing without finger pressure, until you toggle it off;<br />--the Aquarius comes with three Classic Jet tips, versus two with the Ultra<br />--the Aquarius includes a massage mode (have to admit that I don't use this at all)<br/>--the Aquarius includes an LED Function Indicator (ehh)<br />--the Aquarius includes a Timer/Pacer (I use this every day and know that I would stop sooner than I should if it weren't on there)<br />--the Ultra doesn't include anything that the Aquarius does not<br /><br />Features That Are Identical Between the Aquarius and the Ultra<br />--both come in black and white (Aquarius, this page; [[ASIN:B00CU9VF2Q Waterpik Ultra White and Black available here]];<br />--same water pressure<br />--same flow rate<br />--same pulse rate<br />--both have 10 pressure settings<br />--the tips rotate 360 degrees<br />--water capacity both in volume and in seconds<br />--both have covered water reservoirs<br />--almost identical weight: 1.46 pounds for this Aquarius and 1.48 for the Ultra<br />--both have three-year warranties<br />--both only have plugs for North America<br /><br />SOME OTHER MODELS AVAILABLE:<br /><br />Waterpik Complete Care is still available for $10 more and gives you a shorter warranty (2 years instead of 3), no massage mode, no LED indicators, and fewer tips. Thumbs down.<br /><br />If you're really price sensitive OR if you want to use medicaments OR you really hate filling the reservoir, the Waterpik Classic Pro is $30 less expensive on the Waterpik site (on Amazon, prices vary) includes a medicament reservoir, and holds up to 35 ounces (Aquarius and Ultra hold 22 ounces) but you will not get:<br />--the good reviews that the Aquarius and Ultra have; Classic Pro is not nearly as well-liked;<br />--the option of a black-colored model;<br />--the maximum water pressure of 100 PSI (it's 90 PSI instead)<br />--four pressure settings: you get only six pressure settings instead of ten (but honestly, how many people need the subtlety of more than six settings?);<br />--the super-important-to-me Timer/Pacer<br />--water control on the handle (it works like the Ultra: you have to hold a button down);<br />--a covered reservoir;<br />--covered tip storage;<br />--massage mode;<br />--LED Function Indicator;<br />--the ability to use any tips other than the Classic, the Pik Pocket and the Tongue Cleaner (Waterpik does not make compatible Orthodontic tips, Plaque Seeker tips, or Toothbrush tips for the Waterpik Classic Pro)<br />--the third year of warranty, Classic only comes with a tow-year warranty.<br /><br />I hope this review has been helpful to you. Please feel free to leave comments, as you can see, I have responded to the only question asked, and am happy to answer more. And I'd very much appreciate a &#34;Yes&#34; click if you did find this review at all helpful. (I have dreams of one day qualifying for the VINE reviewer program...)<br /><br />IMPORTANT HEALTH UPDATES (2/19/2017): WATERPIKING SAVES LIVES, MAYBE YOURS!<br /><br />THE LIFESAVING UPDATE: My Primary Care Physician just informed me that PLAQUE in the MOUTH CAUSES PLAQUE in the ARTERIES AND VEINS! !! ! !! That was a big surprise to me. Now I'm REALLY going to use this baby twice a day (like I told my dental hygienist I do &#60;w&#62;).<br /><br />A DENTAL HYGIENE BEST-PRACTICES UPDATE: My Primary also told me that using flossing brushes (like the Pixters my dentist told me to use) actually transfers bacteria from the first tooth to the second, and from the first and second to the third, and so on. Unless of course you use a new one for each tooth, each time. IMHO, they're way too expensive for that! So, she suggested using one per tooth but on a less frequent basis, and using the Waterpik two times, full time, every single day instead.
  318. Love, love, love this! I always hated flossing, especially when the string would cut my gums. After using this Waterpik, my mouth feels and tastes SO clean! I add a few drops of mouthwash (AFTER filling or you get a bunch of foam), which adds to the fresh feeling. Warning - Keep extra towels around to clean the area around your sink and mirror until you get used to controlling the water, LOL! Just keep your head down toward the sink and you'll be fine. And I love seeing everything wash away down the drain instead of falling off the floss, or worse when it goes flying in the air to land somewhere unknown! I find I will use this at least every other day if not every day, which was rarely the case when I used to use 'string'.

I convinced him to get into the habit of irrigating at least every evening just before bedtime. Pieces of grizzle, celery string, and many other foodstuffs are easily removed by the pressure of the water coming from the system. The overall quality of my teeth has improved just from using this product. Of course, this is no substitute for use of a brush quality toothpaste. It is a great way to supplement those tools and I found an easy substitute for regular floss.<br /><br />One thing that I didn't think I would use it and found it very satisfying is the massage option for the WaterPik. I use it a couple times a week on gums and tongue and find it oddly satisfying. I would strongly recommend this product for anyone that is a part-time flosser, and even those dedicated to the stringer tape would likely find this product of great benefit.

  433. Not what I expected. I had a waterpik a long time ago which worked well for a long time. When it finally stopped working, I went back to normal dental floss. Fast forward many years.....So when I saw the Waterpik Aquarius Water Flosser on Amazon, I decided to give it a try. Bought 2 actually. One for me, the other as a gift. The one I sent as a gift, unfortunately, was defective (the on/off switch was stuck) and had to be returned. The second one - bought for me - works, technically. Water does shoot out of the nozzle. As for whether it's effective - I would have to say NO. Water shoots out of the nozzle like it's supposed to, but at least 25% of the water and water pressure is lost from the connection joint (where the flossing nozzle connects to the hand held device). Of course, the higher you set the pressure, the more water comes out (both sides). This means that the water reservoir isn't really big enough to floss well without reloading, which is annoying......And the unit is very loud.

  442. I bought this back in January (we're in June) at the recommendation of my dental hygienist. She's been telling me for years to get a waterpik flosser. I don't know why I waited so long to buy one! Anyway..I've been using this daily in the evening since my last dental cleaning in January and I just returned home from my dental cleaning. I was amazed that for the first time in years I didn't spit blood out while rinsing after my cleaning. My hygienist was very happy with out my gums looked and even more pleased at how they showed no signs of sensitivity during the dental cleaning.<br /><br />Keep in mind if you have sensitive gums you will probably bleed so you might be comforatble with a lower setting and slowly work your way up. It took me a few about two months before I went to the highest setting without bleeding. You would be amazed and grossed at the yucky food particles that this thing gets out that brushing simply can't...just that alone will make you want to include the waterpik as part of your daily routine for the rest of your life!<br /><br />As far as the mechanics of this once compared to the older model...I had used both for a week before deciding on the new model just because of appearance, on/off switch on handle and the more compact it is for my sink space....I gave older model to my sister and she loves it. IMO both get the job done which is most important. I also like that I don't have to hold down the ON button while flossing, this could be a bit awkward while having to maneuver the pic in various positions while flossing but it's manageable. This new model also is lighter weight but I never had it once topple over on my uneven bathroom sink so that's not an issue for me.<br /><br />I've read many other reviews that persuaded me to get the waterpik, hope my review might help someone in return. I am so thrilled and very thankful for this product. I'd give it 10 stars if I could!! If your on the fence about which model to buy, don't be their both equal in performance...if price is an issue you can't go wrong with either, whichever is the cheapest go for it! Your gums will be thankful!!

  493. The Waterpik Aquarius is my wife's and my first water flosser. We've only had it for a few weeks, so my five-star rating is just for the flosser itself and not for how effective it is for removing plaque. We purchased the Waterpik flosser on the recommendation of our dentist, because my wife had to have braces. We like it very much and enjoy just how absolutely easy it is to use and care for. Of course after using first regular then electric toothbrushes all our lives, using something entirely new and alien to us was somewhat awkward at first. But after just a couple of uses we found nothing awkward about the water flosser at all. We are both very comfortable with it. It certainly flushes out food particles caught between your teeth much better than regular floss does. We both think it's a great piece of equipment to add to our dental hygiene regimen, and we find nothing wrong with it. The complaints about it &#34;feeling cheap&#34;, about difficulty returning the hand-held unit to its mount, about difficulty with retracting the hose back into place, all seem utterly and totally petty. Just how much cleaner will our teeth be, and how much healthier will our gums be? Well the Waterpik is just a tool. How well we use it and how diligent we are about our dental health will determine that. My wife and I will continue to use our electric toothbrush for brushing, but we look forward to the improvement the Waterpik Aquarius Water Flosser will bring to our overall dental hygiene.
  494. Waterpik has reduced my need for flossing (not eliminated my need) - and improved my overall oral hygine - short story: I love it!
  495. Exactly what I wanted. Arrived fast. Thanks!
  496. I like this unit very much, but at first I gave it only four stars because of one problem that I thought must be a small design flaw. On this unit there is an on/off switch on the handle, as well as a power button on the base. The instructions say to turn on the power button, then when you have the tip in your mouth to turn on the switch on the handle, and turn the handle switch off when finished. HOWEVER, I found it almost impossible to turn the water switch on and off without using two thumbs. I simply could not do it while it was in my mouth, even after I had used for nearly a month. When I called the company I was told just to work the switch back and forth several times for a few days, but this did not work So, I resorted to simply turning the power button on and off, and ignoring the on/off switch on the handle. This seems to work fine (and I found myself wondering why they even had a switch on the handle) .BUT I also went to the company website and recorded my comments there. I was pleasantly surprised to receive a phone call from a company representative just a few days later, telling me that this was unusual and that they would immediately sent me a replacement handle. It came in just a few days, and it worked beautifully! So I am really pleased with this company. the flosser works very well. I use it after I have brushed and flossed with regular floss, and nearly always I will dislodge at least a little more of something that was not dislodged before.I had a portable water flosser that I bought back in 2007, but it finally wore out, so I decided to replace it with this one.I am glad I did. If you buy one and have a problem similar to the one I described, don't hesitate to notify the company (through their website worked better for me than by telephone).<br />One thing I do not understand is why the company recommends replacing the tips every 6 months. I don't see how usage can affect the tips.

  534. I might have liked this product more if I hadn't gotten the Philips air pick instead. As a caveat I have to confess that at the moment I have a couple of teeth that need some serious attention from a dentist. These teeth turned out to be extremely sensitive to this Waterpik Water Flosser. I used this on one of my problem teeth right after setting it up, and my jaw was throbbing for minutes afterwards. So if your teeth - whether one or all of them - are temperature sensitive, there could be a lot of time you wouldn't be able to use this. The Philips, on the other hand, I have been able to use, even though it utilizes blasts of air (or mouthwash or water if you have filled its reservoir with it.<br /><br />The other problem I had was testing it alongside the Philips. I found that if I used the Philips first, the WaterPik was unable to find much else to clean. But if I reversed it, significant amounts of plaque or other things were dislodged by the Philips that the WaterPik mixed. So I ended up giving the WaterPik to a friend with the intention of using only the Philips in the future.
  535. I've loved waterpiks since I was little (and mostly used it as a little squirtgun to make a mess in the bathroom), so I was excited to get to try a new one, as I've had my old set for almost 10 years.<br /><br />This waterpik is a bit more compact than the version I had, but the capacity is about the same and it comes with a ton of accessories (many of which I'd lost from my old one). The good news is the old ones I still have fit this set, so I have some spares.<br /><br />This waterpik is noticably quieter than my older one, I can use it on full blast in the master bathroom without disturbing my sleeping partner.<br /><br />My only complaint is the way the hose is coiled. It's a bit of a pain to get back into the holder and it's a tad springy so sometimes it makes it awkward to use. I'd really like them to use a nicer quality, un-coiled hose that maybe has a take-up reel or some other option for storage. It's a pretty minor complaint though.<br /><br />Like every waterpik I've used before, your mouth and teeth will feel exceptionally clean after using this. Even with a good brushing, I seem to always get a decent amount of debris out with this pik, without the pain and annoyance of regular flossing.

  581. I was skeptical at first, but after having this for a few years now I'm glad I tried it.<br /><br />PROS:<br />• Easy to Use - Fill it with warm water or water mixed with mouthwash (same amount of mouthwash you'd normally use diluted in the water), choose the intensity and your head attachment, put the wand end in your mouth, make sure the switch on the wand is turned on (I leave mine turned on), turn the power button on, start at a back molar and work your way forward, keeping your head tilted forward and lips puckered so the water pours out into the sink.<br />• Efficacy - More effective and faster than flossing. At least that's what the internet says, but here's my point: I never would floss, but this is so easy and quick I can do it every night with no worry. It also leaves your mouth feeling refreshed and rinsed before you brush and mouthwash.<br />• Oral Hygiene - The water pushes bacteria and food particles out, effectively doing the same job as flossing and mouthwashing. It also helps promote periodontal health by stimulating circulation in your gums, which can help them to heal faster and fight infections better.<br />• No pain or bleeding if you just start, unlike flossing. Just start on the lowest sensitivity and work your way up.<br />• Multiple Options - With various heads so you can actually brush your teeth with it, use different spray types, and the pulsating massage mode for massaging gums.<br /><br />CONS:<br />• Expensive, especially compared to floss.<br />• The on/off switch is difficult to change with one hand. This doesn't affect me though as I leave it on and just use the power button on the machine to start and stop water flow.<br />• Can be loud, if you're trying to floss while others are asleep.<br />• Not portable like floss is. Even if you get the handheld version (terrible idea) you have to dispose of the water, so you can't floss while you read or watch TV like with standard floss.<br /><br />TIPS:<br />• Putting a washcloth or grip pad (like what you line cabinets with or what you open the pickle jar with) under the unit to help lower the vibrations<br />• Once a month do a cleaning rinse: Clean the basin out with vinegar, allowing it to soak for an hour and put the wand tips in with it - this will kill odor causing germs. Pour that out and do a full hot water rinse to get the vinegar out, then do a hydrogen peroxide rinse. The peroxide will kill any mildew spores inside the tubing.<br />• Don't leave water in the basin, or put any non-liquid or sticky additives in. I've put mouthwash in before as a rinse aid, but that's it. You don't want stuff clogging the tubing.<br /><br />UPDATE: After over two years it's still performing like new, staying clean inside and out, and my teeth have never been healthier! I've also not seen any signs of leaking like others have experienced. The only time I get water on the counter is if it runs along the hose and drips off.d (like what you line cabinets with or what you open the pickle jar with) under the unit to help lower the vibrations<br />• Once a month do a cleaning rinse: Clean the basin out with vinegar, allowing it to soak for an hour and put the wand tips in with it - this will kill odor causing germs. Pour that out and do a full hot water rinse to get the vinegar out, then do a hydrogen peroxide rinse. The peroxide will kill any mildew spores inside the tubing.<br />• Don't leave water in the basin, or put any non-liquid or sticky additives in. I've put mouthwash in before as a rinse aid, but that's it. You don't want stuff clogging the tubing.<br /><br />UPDATE: After over two years it's still performing like new, staying clean inside and out, and my teeth have never been healthier! I've also not seen any signs of leaking like others have experienced. The only time I get water on the counter is if it runs along the hose and drips off.

The extra tips are color coded as white, grey, and blue respectively.<br /><br />The other tips in this package include a deep cleaning tip, a tip to clean bracers, and a toothbrush tip. The book doesn't really explain how to use any of these extra tips, so I would ask your orthodontist for further information about these before using them. Or you can just use them however you want, doesn't matter.<br /><br />The reason why I didn't give this product 5 stars is because I'm not entirely sure how effective this actually is in terms of cleaning your teeth. I've brushed my teeth, used this, and flossed, and the floss still picked up some stuff off my teeth even though it was the last to be used. This certainly does not replace flossing, at least. But decent product overall. Just a bit hard to measure the actual effectiveness.

  611. Does everything it's advertised to do. 10 levels of intensity of pulsing water stream to choose from. You're also able to choose between gum massage or water flossing with the push of a button. I see some people reviewing say it's difficult to remove the tip. Well, if you slide the side button up, the tip pops off instantly and easily. To re-attach, just slip it into the handle until it snaps in place. Doesn't get much easier than that. I also read where the wand button is &#34;difficult&#34; to move. When the unit is in the &#34;off&#34; mode, the button slides easily. When you turn it on, it's a tiny bit difficult because of the built up water pressure............but I didn't find it all that bad at all and don't understand what all the fuss is about. I slid the handle button on and off with minimal thumb pressure at setting 1 then dialed it up to 10. Once the water was gone, I was able to retract the handle thumb button easily. Comes with a total of 7 attachments but no &#34;case&#34; to store them in. I did find that Amazon carries the &#34; Waterpik Convenient Hygienic Sturdy Storage Case for Replacement Tips , 6 Count&#34;. It's a tip storage case that comes with 6 tips--- 2 classic jets, 2 plaque seekers and 2 Orthodontic tips all for around 15 bucks. They also sell just the case without any replacement tips for around 9 bucks. The tips that come with this Storage case do fit the WP600, as well as several other units Waterpik sells. For a full list of compatible units, go online to Waterpik for a complete list.<br />I highly recommend using warm water so it's not as big shock to your teeth, especially if you've got tooth sensitivity issues.

I can already tell already my gums are happier and I will continue to use it. One of these should be standard in anyone's dental routine.

  666. I love this thing. I've never been a good flosser, partly because I have a permanent retainer behind my front teeth and also because I never got into the habit of flossing as a child. Several years ago, I bought a cordless water flosser, which was an absolute disaster. It was large, held only a few seconds worth of water, and was nearly impossible to maneuver in your mouth. I forced myself to get serious about flossing, and used threaders and string with great results, but tartar was still visible around the wire.<br /><br />After a single use of this, the impossible to floss tartar was knocked out. After seeing a dentist for the first time in over a year, he commented on how clean my teeth were.<br /><br />Why I strongly recommend this:<br />1) The reservoir last long enough to clean your entire mouth. I seem to finish my top/bottom path right as the tank gets to empty.<br /><br />2) the hose/handheld device is very well designed. This feels much like holding a toothbrush, and I've never had any issues with the hose getting in the way. The utensil is small enough that you can rotate it easily in your mouth.<br /><br />3) I lean over the sink and 'look down' when I use this. All water lands in the sink. I've had no problems with water coming out anywhere near the tank/pump.<br /><br />4) Tips are super easy to change<br /><br />Areas for improvement:<br />1) The tip holder is hard to access. I have to remove the tank to get the tips. This isn't a big deal since I do not use the holder, and only use one tip.<br /><br />2) The provided tips are angled at 45 degrees or so. It seems difficult to use these behind the very back teeth. It would be nice if they provided guidance on how to clean the gumline of the very back teeth.<br /><br />Misc:<br />1) Cleaning: When I first got the device, I filled the tank about 1/4 full of rubbing alcohol and water, and then rank the solution through. I followed this up with 2 full tanks of water. I also gave the tips a quick bath in rubbing alcohol.<br /><br />2) The package comes with several tips. I use the standard one.

  682. I like the Waterpik brand. My previous Waterpik which was bought over ten years ago, still worked. However, I thought it was time to upgrade.<br /><br />I really love how this model looks. I have a weakness for pistachio nuts and this Waterpik does a great job with getting the left over particles that get stuck between my teeth out. I don't even need to set it on it's strongest setting (10). The water pressure is nice and strong at level 5. I utilize the floss setting the most and it seems adequate enough. The brush is okay but not that great.   683. This model (WP-660) of the Waterpik is the best one yet.<br />The best improvement by far over the last one that I used is the On/Off switch located on the handle.<br /><br />My previous one had a button that had to be pushed to keep the water flow OFF. I thought that was kind of backwards, pushing the button to turn it off - my bathroom mirror and walls can back me up on that!<br /><br />I have only used 2 of the 5 tips available. There are actually 7 tips but 3 are the same tip (classic jet tip):<br />Classic Jet Tip and Pik Pocket Tip.<br />The Jet Tip is the standard tip for most water flossers and it works great.<br />The Pik Pocket is unique because it creates a extremely fine stream of water and the rubber nozzle allows you to get in between teeth and into any crevices that you can't normally reach with the other tips. I especially like this for the area behind my back molars and the gaps where my wisdom teeth used to be.<br /><br />One other feature that I like is the small footprint this waterpik has on the bathroom sink counter. Does not take up much space at all.<br /><br />Great product and thank you for the ON/OFF switch!

The button is rather stiff and not easy to move back and forth. For something that has had such a high consumer rating, how is it that I've had this difficulty? (Will use it for a while to see if the button travel improves. If not, will return the Waterpik to Amazon)

  691. After a couple less than stellar check-ups and a cavity that I had to get filled, I decided it was time to start taking oral hygiene a bit more seriously. This meant above all else, flossing. I was not good about keeping up with it and I generally hated it. Flossing is usually a painful and bloody ordeal for me, obviously because of my lack of flossing, but it was pretty hard to motivate myself to keep doing it. That's when I decided to start looking at other options.<br /><br />I had heard of water flossers, but I had no idea they worked as well as they do. After a bit of research and reading, I decided on the Waterpik Aquarius.<br /><br />My first time using it was to put it nicely, gross. It dislodged bits and chunks from various parts of my mouth that had been sitting there for who knows how long. I could even smell how gross the stuff getting knocked out was. But when it was all said and done my mouth felt great and cleaner than it had in a long time. Followed with a brush with a Sonicare, and it was like I just left the dentist. My gums felt really good afterwards and weren't a bloody mess (although surprisingly, there was still some blood. I'll probably tone down the pressure setting next time).<br /><br />Flossing with a Waterpik is no longer a chore, it's actually kind of enjoyable. I intend to make this a part of my nightly routine and I'm actually kind of excited for my next dentist appointment now.<br /><br />If you have had issues flossing but want to do something about it, you should really look into one of these. You won't regret it.

  831. My first experience with a water pic so I'm unable to compare it to others. Problem 1) is the inadequate documentation. It seems to be written with an experienced user in mind. Yes, much is obvious but still.... 2) Due to 1) I wasn't really sure of how it was supposed to turn on/off. The slider was so stiff I was afraid I'd break it. (An experienced user told me it would, and it did. But in the interim I was starting/stopping water flow with the line-in ON/OFF switch, not a good practice with any electrical device, especially not a 110 VAC device in a bathroom. Even now that I know where the slider is I find it slippery and hard to use. I think a simple push-on/push-off would be better. 3) Yes, several tips were supplied but I could have used some details on the intended purpose of each.
  832. Settings and water pressure is good. The waterpik came with 6 attachments which is nice, however the storage compartment only holds 2. The handle at times does not sit well in it's holder.
  833. Works wonderfully, just like at the dentist. Also works great to keep dog/small child at bay when they're screaming for attention.
  834. What a difference from my old Waterpik! It's quieter, looks nicer, takes up less counter space, and the stream is simple to adjust. The reservoir is easier to situate correctly, and the controls are placed for easier on/off. No minuses at all.
  835. The water pic arrived well packaged and fully intact and complete. The flosser was everything the advertising promised and more. Am looking forward to years of clean teeth and healthy gums.
  836. Convenient, effective and simple. Does an excellent job as a water flosser, and extremely easy to use right out of the box.
  837. Works well. Great for irrigation, does it actually power off plaque? Not quite a believer in that at this point but I have not turned up power all the way yet either. Mouth feels quite refreshed and cleaner after using so even if not quite the plaque remover, it is well worth the money. As far as the splashing goes, it is shooting water out of a nozzle, what else would you expect? There is some splashing, but it is manageable.
  838. We love this water pick, works as expected and it's really fun to use it compare to just the thread floss! Highly recommend it!
  839. First one and it is doing a great job. Perhaps to good of a job... Now I need to go to the dentist to get me teeth cleaned. See stuff that shouldn't be there &#34;Tarter&#34; in the last year. Should have bought one of these a long time ago.
  840. I have used older versions of WaterPik and while they worked, I have never been impressed. They were always a necessity. This one has finally met my expectations and exceeded. It delivers just as strong a pulse of water as older versions but with far less water. The massager mode is really nice. This version has a switch to turn on and off water flow on the handle, which is a huge improvement because older styles required you to constantly hold a button to stop water flow or have water fly everywhere. The tips have vastly improved and do a much better job cleaning between teeth, in my periodontal pockets and under my crowns.

  864. Pros:<br />- It does the job of cleaning between teeth very well.<br />- Looks great on the bathroom counter. (I know looks shouldn't be so important... But if it doesn't look good - you probably will try to hide it from view.) This thing can sit there and be drooled-over by your guests. (hopefully not drooled-on).<br />- Much easier than flossing.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- Only when compared to the WaterPik Ultra do we see flaws; 1- more expensive 2- the extra features are more razzle-dazzle but not really needed. 3- it's lighter and narrower than the Ultra and so it feels more top-heavy. Not a good thing if you happen to knock it over.<br />-It's water reservoir does not hold enough water to clean my whole mouth in one go.<br /><br />Thank you<br /><br />What works for me: I mix a few tablespoons of Hydrogen Peroxide for extra-cleaning power. But don't do this if you can't keep the water from getting into your throat (it takes lots of practice).
  865. I purchased a water flosser because everyone I know swears by it. Of course, it is easier just to get piece of dental floss and have at it. I had high expectations when I purchased this product but only got so-so results. First of all, you get 6 different tools/heads to use with the apparatus that are good for general use or for more advanced dental issues. The drawback is that the storage unit is under the water reservoir lid and only holds 2 tools. Set up is easy. Before first use, the instructions advise to flush some of the water in the sink. When I did this some black debris came out so don't skip this step! After first use it was a complete disaster. Water was dripping out to the base of the hand unit and also the reservoir. I made sure everything was inserted properly and it was. I am not sure if some of the debris was still stuck somewhere but the unit eventually stopped leaking and all was fine. I used the toothbrush tip and the orthodontic tip my mouth felt clean. I admit my mouth feels better after a good flossing. A huge drawback to this unit is that it is a lot noisier than I suspected. I will think I will still use this on occasion but I will keep flossing with good old-fashioned string as part of my normal routine.

  868. I used to dread the quarterly visits to my periodontist...I had several 6mm pockets around my rear molars. Since I started using a water-pik regularly, the pockets have shrunk by 1-2mm and the good doctor is no longer grousing at me.<br /><br />Outside of occasionally spraying the mirror, wife and dog, a water-pik is easy to use. You just want to be careful to start with it set to a low power and work up to something stronger. Also, if your teeth are at all cold sensitive, use warm water. Otherwise, it's quite an experience. :-)
  869. This works great with warm water and a shot of Listerine
  870. ehhh, just ok nothing more
  871. Unit did a great job no problems and maybe even too much pressure at first, takes a bit to get use to it but after that it does a great job.
  872. I'm not a dentist or dental hygienist , or even a (fluid mechanics, perhaps) physicist, so I can't tell you whether the Waterpik WP-660 \\"Professional\\" Water Flosser is better than a thorough brushing followed by brushing. However, if your dental professional recommends a WaterPik, I *can* report that I'm very happy with this model, although some of the various tips seem a little superfluous.<br /><br />Unlike some reviewers here, I've had no problems with the truly convenient on/off switch located on the handle; the switch enables you to turn the machine on while the device is in your mouth, preventing the extra-oral spraying all over your bathroom. Good job there! Nor have I had any problem seating the waterpik back in its holder, or noticed any mold forming. (They recommend cleaning with vinegar solution, oh, and YES, you can use this with mouth wash-just rinse the device afterwards.)<br /><br />A few highlights include:<br /><br />1. A nice continuous (it does not adjust at \\"click points\\") power dial, and the very real difference in these power settings. Depending on preferences and the health of your gums, you can very easily adjust from a very light stream to one so powerful it may hurt in certain areas. You can even change the jet stream power while using it.<br /><br />2. Adequate water supply. The built-in tank (it's well held in place by a thin plastic cover) holds enough water to do a thorough cleaning of all your teeth and gums. If you sometimes want a little extra gum massage/cleaning, it's very fast and easy to just fill up the small, light plastic tank again.<br /><br />3. Smaller footprint, semi-stylish design. This will take up less room on a counter top (check the dimensions given by Amazon above) than Waterpiks from the past, and it's not nearly as unwieldy looking. While hard white plastic with an attached cleaning device sticking up (see pictures) isn't going to enhance your bathroom's appearance, the look is a definite improvement compared to some of the clunkers I had several years ago.<br /><br />4. Overall quality. Although I've used this for only a couple of months, I'm impressed with the overall functioning of the Waterpik. It's been reliable, it has a strong motor, the timer feature (so that you can pace your cleaning) works every time, and the power is impressive. There's a massage feature that give you a pulse rather than a continuous flow. I didn't see the need for this at first, but I now prefer it when my purpose is to massage the gums only.<br /><br />5.It's a bit noisy, but not more than I expected. However, if your bathroom (or wherever the heck you use this) is close to a bedroom where your partner sleeps, you'll want to close all doors. It might even be better to Waterpik when he or she is awake. The dog seems neutral. The tips that are placed into the handle are locked with a small twist of a circular ring. Very easy to do, but there is a bit of vibration to the top that is mildly annoying. I say \\"mildly\\" because it does not seem to affect performance; on the other hand, my irritation comes from a sense that it should have a tighter fit. Just an engineering aesthetic preference, not something that should keep you from buying this.<br /><br />Those Bells and Whistles... Timers, LED light displays, a closed compartment for two extra tips, and five types of tips, I wonder if they really make much of a difference, especially the tips (the timer and LED work fine and seem pretty standard on dental appliances these days). The tips though... You get a thin hard tip to deliver water \\"deep into periodontal pockets,\\" a flat one to clean your tongue, a sort of soft tiny brush tip to brush teeth \\"and all around [the] orthodontic bracket, \\" a toothbrush tip (standard looking circular brush), and the bristled \\"plaque-seeker\\" tip (\\"Gently brush along the gumline, pausing briefly between teeth to gently brush and allow the water to flow between the teeth.\\") [Quotes from the very thorough and easy-to-understand included manual.]<br /><br />Some of these seem not entirely effective to me. For example, using the brush with toothpaste doesn't work that well , because the water stream volume quickly gets rid of the tooth paste. (However, the manual does state it can be used with or without paste). The e plaque-seeker's brush just doesn't seem much better than the general use \\"classic jet tip,\\" but perhaps others will find it helpful. So far, I haven't. Not a big complaint, but I imagine it may add a little to the cost.<br /><br />Summary. I'm very satisfied with this new Waterpik and enjoy using it. My mouth *feels* extra clean afteruse. Is it cleaner than doing a thorough flossing...I don't know. However, you might consider whether you'll take better care of your teeth with a well-working gadget that is easy to use and leaves a subjective feeling of CLEAN TEETH. The gumline massage capability seems superior to flossing. If you're not a skeptic, consider the company's claim that \\"Flossers are clinically proven to remove up to 99.9% of plaque from treated areas in 3 seconds. And for healthier gums, they are clinically proven up to 50% more effective for improving gum health vs. string floss.\\"<br /><br />I'd like to see the price about $10 lower than the current non-discounted price, so it's not great, but reasonably good value. If it motivates you to clean you teeth and gums more often than before, it's an excellent value! : ) As always, consult your oral hygiene specialist to see whether the Waterpik is a wise choice for you.orough and easy-to-understand included manual.]<br /><br />Some of these seem not entirely effective to me. For example, using the brush with toothpaste doesn't work that well , because the water stream volume quickly gets rid of the tooth paste. (However, the manual does state it can be used with or without paste). The e plaque-seeker's brush just doesn't seem much better than the general use \\"classic jet tip,\\" but perhaps others will find it helpful. So far, I haven't. Not a big complaint, but I imagine it may add a little to the cost.<br /><br />Summary. I'm very satisfied with this new Waterpik and enjoy using it. My mouth *feels* extra clean afteruse. Is it cleaner than doing a thorough flossing...I don't know. However, you might consider whether you'll take better care of your teeth with a well-working gadget that is easy to use and leaves a subjective feeling of CLEAN TEETH. The gumline massage capability seems superior to flossing. If you're not a skeptic, consider the company's claim that \\"Flossers are clinically proven to remove up to 99.9% of plaque from treated areas in 3 seconds. And for healthier gums, they are clinically proven up to 50% more effective for improving gum health vs. string floss.\\"<br /><br />I'd like to see the price about $10 lower than the current non-discounted price, so it's not great, but reasonably good value. If it motivates you to clean you teeth and gums more often than before, it's an excellent value! : ) As always, consult your oral hygiene specialist to see whether the Waterpik is a wise choice for you.

  954. Thumb on off slide is hard to use.
  955. For about a year now, I've used the Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser and loved the unit. It got my teeth clean, was simple to use, and made dentist visits much more bearable knowing I didn't huge pockets in my gums anymore. Recently I got the opportunity to try out the Waterpik Aquarius Water Flosser. The upgrades to the unit, while few, are quite nice to have.<br /><br />First off, the huge cover that stored all the Waterpik pieces is finally gone. I hated having all the pieces in the lid of the Ultra Water Flosser. In the Aquarius, you can store your two favorite pieces in a space between the reservoir and the plastic side. All the additional pieces I placed in a drawer. This helped make the unit much more visually appealing and I no longer have to worry about pieces falling out of the lid every time I open the reservoir.<br /><br />Another update is that there is a pulse that helps time you so you move from places to place in your mouth. The water pulse goes off at the 30 and 60 second time. This pulse didn't really help much for me as I tend to move the pik through my mouth slowly anyways. It was interesting to use the new &#34;massage&#34; feature where the water pulses continually. The pulsing may be more appealing to others, as I didn't find it very useful.<br /><br />The final upgrade on the Aquarius unit is the &#34;on/off&#34; switch on the handle of the Waterpik. This was another great addition to the pik. On the Ultra Water you would have to push and hold down a button to keep water from squirting all over the place. Because the water is now switched, I can now turn on the unit without having to get squirted should I forget to hold down the button.<br /><br />Overall, the difference between the Aquarius and Ultra Water are few, but appreciated. Both units do a fantastic job at getting your mouth super clean - it's like having a dentist clean all the time! I use the Waterpik everyday and can't recommend it enough to family and friends. It's a great tool if you don't like to floss and will help maintain good teeth health. Highly recommended.great tool if you don't like to floss and will help maintain good teeth health. Highly recommended.
  956. Would have given 5 stars but it is really annoying that the on/off slide button which controls the water flow on the hand piece is super STIFF. I have to use 2 hands to slide the button, which usually ends up with water shooting everywhere! Stupid design!
  957. Easy to use and as effective as promised.
  958. Outstanding appliance. I wish I had found this years ago. I brush carefully and well and this appliance still gets otherwise trapped food particles out. Worth the investment and makes your mouth feel GREAT.
  959. This product is very effective. No more struggling to get traditional floss around my fingers and into my mouth!<br /><br />But, tell me. Am I the only one who pressure washed the bathroom wall with their first use? (This can be messy)
  960. I personally did not like this water pick as it is very messy to use and launches water in all directions.   969. great machine, works as advertised

  971. It works as well as everyone says, but it's VERY loud. My roommates hate it.
  972. My wife and I have been using Waterpiks for years now along with Sonicare toothbrushes. We have the previous generation Waterpik Ultra so that is what this model will be compared to.<br /><br />The main upgrade on the Aquarius is the on/off switch on the handle. This is a huge bonus, as the previous model had a &#34;hold&#34; button that would shoot water all over the bathroom if let go by accident. You eventually got used to always pointing the tip towards the sink, but this was my main complaint about the old model. With the new Aquarius, the on/off switch prevents this problem and is a huge bonus.<br /><br />This new Aquarius model is also much better looking, although I really don't care about the design, since when it is not in use, it is stored inside my cabinet. As far as features and power goes, there is no difference to me. The massage mode is a gimmick and I cannot feel any difference in the &#34;power&#34; of the water between my teeth.<br /><br />As other reviewers have noted, yes this unit is significantly lighter in weight, which does cause the unit to move around more when using the handle, especially when almost empty of water. I think Waterpik should have increased the weight and stability of the base unit.<br /><br />The new Aquarius is much more quiet, but does that justify an upgrade? hardly.<br /><br />Final Verdict: If you can find the previous model at a discounted price, buy it. Just be sure to get used to the &#34;hold&#34; button and avoid shooting water all over your bathroom. If you already have the previous model.... Don't bother upgrading until your unit needs to be replaced. If you need to buy your first Waterpik and this is the only model available, then go for it. We really like the on/off switch on the handle. We've had our Ultra model for over 2 years now and it has functioned flawlessly, so I expect the same with this new model.<br /><br />Tip: My wife and I use warm water with a capful of hydrogen peroxide. It doesn't taste thatbad, but works wonders to kill bacteria, whitens teeth, and disinfects the unit all at once. Just don't swallow the peroxide. Yes it's safe and was recommended to us by our dentist.<br /><br />Hope this helps.
  973. Excellent model, we love it! It cleans so nice between teeth and around gums!
  974. I've been using Waterpik products for a lot of years. I find they are a great way to keep my gums healthy. In particular I like to use the Waterpik to shoot dilute solutions of saltwater or water + apple cider vinegar (every now and then) between my teeth where a toothbrush can't reach.<br /><br />But for daily use just plain water is good. My favorite attachment is the bristle brush because I can shoot water between my tight teeth while brushing them at the same time.<br /><br />Combine traditional floss with this Waterpik and an Oral-B Professional Deep Sweep and you have a powerful dental care combo.
  975. This Waterpik is similar to other Waterpik/oral irrigators/water flossers I've used in the past. It is most useful for irrigating damaged tissue due to oral surgery. Because that is a small niche, these devices have been rebranded as water flossers. I can see a use for it as a clean up after doing actual flossing, but there's no way that water flossing with this device is comparable to actually using a piece of floss.<br /><br />However, using this device does leave your mouth feeling a bit cleaner. What I do not care for is the way that as soon as you start the machine, water starts pumping through it. There is a regulator on the applicator, but the design seems backwards--it should default to not allowing water to pass through and make you press it in order to allow water to pass through. As it is, you'll be squirting water places you might not like to.<br /><br />This is a perfectly fine device, but if you are after clean teeth and healthy gums, I would get a Panasonic electric toothbrush and stick to flossing by hand. However, if this is the coup de grace of your oral hygiene routine, you'll find it works well to flush away any detritus and leave your mouth feeling even cleaner and fresher.<br /><br />Recommended with caveats.
  976. While I do not use the Waterpik every day, it is a nice complement to daily brushing/flossing. The pressure is adjustable and it is nicer looking than the old beige &#34;pik&#34; pf the past. Easy to use, and great for those with braces, gets the gunk out!

Better still, when I am done, the handle fits easily into the v-shaped holder as the coiled plastic hose slides right into place. The assortment of tips seems irrelevant to me, as does the 'massage' mode on the dial. I read another review written by someone who had the same problem and his 2nd unit also broke after a few weeks. If this happens to me (again), I will purchase one from a real store like Target or Walmart so I I know who is selling me a product and that the product works. I wonder if these units are on sale because they are a bad batch from the manufacturer and were meant to be thrown out or recycled. Maybe they're really old. Who knows!

  1024. I learned on first usage not to start the thing up unless I was leaning over the sink; otherwise, expect a big splashy spray on your counter, backsplash, and mirror. Seems like common sense, but I guess I wasn't thinking. And start with one of the slower speeds; #10 is like a super-focused power washer--not exaggerating. I started cautiously at #2, and I've settled in at #4, which is just right for a good flossing. I haven't used the massage setting. The product does a good job, and since I leave it on my bathroom counter, there's no &#34;setup&#34; and &#34;put away&#34; chore. Filling and emptying the reservoir is easy-peasy. I haven't tried but one of the attachments, but the main one (in the picture) works very well for my purposes. I've also added a shot of mouthwash to the water in the reservoir once, and that was nice; be sure to rinse the reservoir afterward and run a few ounces of clear water through to clear the mechanism.

  1063. I bought this to replace an older Water Pik, and it's quite an improvement.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1.The pik has an on/off button, which my old one didn't have. On the old one, I'd have to keep my finger pressed pretty firmly, or water would go all over the place if I wasn't careful. With this, I don't have that problem.<br />2. I like the fact that this has a water well top that is hinged, and doesn't come off. The old one had a removable top, and I would often end up dropping it into the water well. Maybe I'm just extra clumsy, but I hated that.<br />3. Bless Water Pik for making this in different colors! I don't know if they can make it any quieter, but I hope someday they can.<br />2. I went to the Water Pik website, and they had nothing.<br /><br />So, I contacted Water Pik, and they sent me the rebate form. When I got it, the rebate said something about a receipt from a dentist's office, so I contacted them again and said I had bought it from Amazon. They said it would be fine as long as I sent the Amazon receipt along with the rebate form.<br /><br />My rebate got here fairly quickly, so if you're willing to go to some trouble, you can get $15 back!
  1064. This is my review of the Waterpik Aquarius Water Flosser.<br />I bought this product for my daughter with braces. I have used it daily as well. The product is quite compact compared to others I have bought in the past. Its all white design blended well with my bathroom decor. The one I ordered came with a few attachments so it can be used by different members of the family. The water reservoir was big enough to hold the right amount of water for one water flossing. It was easy to add water. Just flip the cover the remove the whole reservoir out to the faucet. The water pressure is adjustable from 1 to 10. I had to use level 10 while my daughter uses about level 8. I found it had enough pressure to remove stuck on food (meat) in between hard to reach crevices in between the back molars. Better than flossing alone.<br /><br />All in all, I recommend it. If you are looking for a water flossing device, this one is quite acceptable and was not as expensive.

And while I still use traditional floss a couple of times a week just to stimulate my gums, I use this twice daily and always feel refreshed. It also can be used with mouthwashes and other liquid rinses if required or recommended by your dentist. The new version is easier than ever to use and comes with different tips for specific needs.

  1113. By far the best! Over the years I've owned the Classic (WP 60/65), and the Ultra (WP-100) and now the Aquarius. The Classic was the loudest and probably the most powerful. The Ultra lasted roughly 5 years before the flosser hose began leaking. The Ultra is built heavier than both but much less powerful. I was sort of glad when I had to replace it. I bought the Aquarius about three weeks ago and loved it, it's more powerful than the Ultra which feels you're getting a much better cleaning. It's lighter, sleek and the holder works fine for me. I was a little hesitant at first after reading some of the reviews about it's quality. But for me this one has the power of the classic but much quieter and a better design than the previous models.
