  1180. You need to ask yourself 3 questions before buying this:<br /><br />1: Do you have plenty of room by a sink to set this while you use it? This is not a small product, and for those of us with stand alone sinks, it may be a tight fit to have it sitting on the side. It works much better for those with sinks set in counters.<br /><br />2: Is the noise of the pump operating going to bother you? It is not very quiet to be honest. I found it to be much louder then I expected and it makes it a problem to use depending on the time of night because of the location to bedrooms with sleeping people (especially if they are light sleepers or noise sensitive)<br /><br />3: Are you ok with water splattering everywhere? Look, you can close your mouth mostly while using it, and the directions specifically show someone with their mouth barely open letting the excess water trickle out and into the sink. But the reality is that for certain spots in your mouth, you have to adjust how your mouth is positioned, or how open it is. No matter what, you will get some water splatter all over the area, and if you are not careful outside the &#34;sink zone&#34;.<br /><br />At the end of the day, this product does work. It cleans better then any flossing device I have ever used. My mouth gets cleaner then ever before. But there are problems and drawbacks that while to some degree I expected, I was not expecting them to be as big a problem as they are. It works, but it also feels like an epic project that takes more time, effort, and care then I ever expected. That's disappointing to me for the price, because I feel like I dont want to, or cant, use it daily.
  1181. I was having some issues, so decided to try this Waterpik. If you are also looking, I would recommend this particular model. What I like about it, that it is small & fits great on my counter.   1186. This Waterpik works great! No issues and plenty of cleaning power.
  1187. This is my second Waterpik. I used my last one so long the plastic was yellowed and ugly. Anyone familar with the Waterpiks will be right at home with this, it is just the updated version of the product with a few improvements. If you havent used one, be warned, once you do you wont be able to get by without one.<br /><br />You will be amazed, and kind of grossed out, when you see how much 'stuff' gets washed from between your teeth when you first start using a Waterpik. I dont mean right after you eat and instead of brushing, I mean AFTER you brush your teeth. The effectiveness of the Waterpik is amazing and you will be astounded at how well it works and how clean your mouth feels afterward. My favorite trick is to add mouthwash to the water when I use it, it leaves a mouth freshness far beyond brushing or mouthwash, and it does it without the harsh burn of mouthwash alone.<br /><br />This unit is smaller than my previous Waterpik, but it is sized to fit on the counter well and holds just the right amount of water. The new features include a 'studder' in the cycle every 30 seconds to allow you to time how long you clean each section of your mouth, just like the electric toothbrushes have now. There are floss and massage settings on the unit, though admittedly I personally think the massage setting is pointless. There are pressure settings on the unit, and another on/off and pressure setting on the handle as well. This makes it very easy to use and prevents spraying your mirrors when you turn the unit on or off. Even the coiled hose is well thought out, as it re-coils effortlessly and holds the handle perfectly in the unit, just like in the photo. The water basin comes off and on easily without any leaks.<br /><br />Overall, this is another great Waterpik and has upgrades worthy of the &#34;new model&#34; product instead of simply a new version of the same product. I have recommended these to my friends, and recommend to anyone wanting a fresher mouth or simpler way to clean between their teeth.
  1188. So my old a-la-Starwars/Sturmtrooper face mask blue bin Waterpik broke, mainly due to the short length of tubing and stretches required to make it reach the oral cavity of this 6'4&#34; user. I pre-ordered the WP-60 and resigned myself to the anemic jet on an old Braun Oral-B dental center.<br /><br />Observations compared to old model:<br /><br />1. Much better looking, the rubberized buttons, and rubber tension reliever at end of wand make it so cool.<br /><br />2. Water tank more ergonomic and easy to see.<br /><br />3. Tubing longer, with wider loops, and stress relief at wand. These two features should make it last longer.<br /><br />3. STRONGER!!! Be warned, it will make your gums hemorrhage at &#34;10&#34;, the new &#34;8&#34; is the old &#34;10&#34; IMHO.<br /><br />4. Massage function not of any use to me.<br /><br />YES, after two weeks of daily use I volunteer to state that it is refreshing to see that this product is an improvement<br />over the old model.<br /><br />I keep going to the dental hygienist every 6mos, hardly any plaque, thank you Waterpik!

  1228. I have had Water Piks in the past, and this one is a clear improvement on past designs. The two on-off switches actually work well together once you get the hang of them. The unit is easy to keep clean and dry (which is important, since these used to be mold factories!), and you get a nice assortment of tips to choose from. I don't find the unit as noisy as previous models either. While flossing is still necessary occasionally, I find that the Water Pik makes my gums and teeth feel cleaner after brushing, without beating up my mouth the way floss tends to, and flossing every night is just a pain. The Water Pik is a pleasure to use every night and really does get stuff you miss by just brushing.

Start with the lowest setting the first few times you use it, and adjust to meet your needs. I did not floss before I tried this, just grabbed it and went for it. It did work great, I also have sensitive teeth, so starting out on low is a great idea if you're like me and need a second to adjust to it, the temp, whatever. I use a bottle of water, not usually the whole thing and it gets my mouth really clean. I also like that you can use any medication or washes your dentist may have given you with this.   1234. Bought it for me and/or kids, one has braces.<br /><br />CON:<br />- it's *not* a real flosser - if you want to replace your regular flossing, you're seriously mistaken. After using this (and emptying two full tanks!), regular flossing still gets a lot of stuff out!!! This alone makes it deserve nothing more than 1 star - wish I could give it -1 star.<br />- the on/off button is extremely poorly designed: while you're &#34;flossing&#34; and water is shooting around, to use the button on handle to turn if off is a Nightmare, and often causes water shooting around. I ended up using the button on the main unit instead but that's huge annoyance - why have a switch on handle at all if it's so hard to impossible to use???<br />- poor design of the handle rest - it's actually a very nice concept and makes it really convenient. there is just one gotcha, a Huge one: after flossing, there is much water left in the handle. There is only one way to rest the handle, and the way will leave water in the handle forever - would have been so much better had it allow handle to rest upside down (to drip-dry)<br /><br />PRO: on day one we had water shooting around the counter everywhere. On day three, we were able to adapt and water is mainly in the mouth.<br />- pretty easy to avoid water mess.<br /><br />Bottom line: Do Not buy if you want to replace your regular flossing. - this one is only good for getting rid of food debris after meal - not for flossing.

  1252. I rate this product as ZERO stars. Not just bad, not just defective, not just non-functional, but also disgusting.<br />When I opened the box, the product had obviously been used and returned, then repackaged and resold.<br />The plastic bag that holds the tips was ripped open, some of the tips were missing, the remainder had clearly been used, or soiled in some way.<br />Now, let's think about that, a PRODUCT YOU PUT IN YOUR MOUTH, used, returned, repackaged and resold, dirty.<br />There are actually laws against that in most states for other products that come into contact with bodily fluids, such as underwear.<br />If this was done by Amazon fulfillment, they should check their records to see who handled the previous return of this item, and fire someone.<br />On top of all that, the pump system did not work. I have a PhD in engineering and have designed many health and medical products, so I should be able to figure out how to turn on a waterpik. This one simply does not work. I checked everything including the voltage on the AC line.<br />SUMMARY:<br />The product sold to me was previously used but sold AS NEW, it was defective, it was unsanitary, just plain disgusting.<br />So, in my assessment, the product was defective, then it was probably returned for that reason, repackaged by some thoughtless idiot, and resold as new.<br />I will not return the product, I'll keep it for show and tell. In my profession and for my many students, it will be an excellent example of everything that could possibly go wrong with the marketing and sale of a health/medical product. For that purpose it is worth the $60.<br /><br />NOTE: in 15 years of on-line shopping, this is only the second negative review I have ever written. I hope it has a positive effect.

It two primary settings for flow (steady stream of water) and &#34;massage (pulses of water). Within each of these settings, the flow can be adjusted via a dial with settings 1 - 10.<br />When you turn the device on, the water doesn't start flowing until you also slide the switch on the hand-held &#34;flosser wand&#34; itself, so you avoid spraying water on your sink before your lips are closed around the wand.<br />The removable/swappable attachments are durable enough for me to put them in the basket of my dishwasher once a week to keep them extra clean. The cord is long enough to leave it on the counter next to the sink without having to reposition the device when using.

  1355. This product works so well, and it is beautifully implemented. The reservoir is easy to empty and dry, the lid keeps the water clean, and it has such a small footprint. With 6 implants including one crown covering two teeth, I was finding it impossible to get them clean using floss, picks and a sonicare toothbrush. The addition of this waterpik made a huge improvement. The wonderful pick called the plaque seeker with two tiny brushes and a central water jet turned out to be just what was needed to get under the crown overlaps and under that permanent bridge. I use it on 4 for this purpose. If you have bridges or implants or problem crowns, this tool will make a difference.

  1360. UPDATE JUNE '17 I'm sorry to say that my review below may no longer be valid. I recenly saw and handled a Waterpik Ultra at Costco, and while it still has the same model number and general appearance of an Ultra, the build quality and weight felt much cheaper and toy-like compared to the older model I have at home. So I defintiely can't claim that the Ultra I handled is any better--and who knows, it might actually be worse--when compared to the Aquarius. Very disappointing for Waterpik to keep the name and model number, while changing the build quality. So in the toss-up between Aquarius and Ultra now, I'd go with whichever one was cheaper, and if prices are similar, I pick the Aquarius for its better appearance.<br /><br />UPDATE OCT '14: The Aquarius has dropped significantly in price since my original review, and is actually slightly cheaper now than the older Ultra. So, with prices so comparable, which unit should you buy? Unless you're really in love with the updated look of the Aquarius, the Ultra still remains the better choice for the reasons I mention below. Also take a look at the video in the &#34;Most Helpful Favorable Review,&#34; where you can really see the cheap construction of the Aquarius, and how sloppily the hose holsters into the unit compared to the Ultra. This sort of negates its one advantage--the cleaner-looking design--and you'll be wrangling to holster that hose on a daily basis. No thanks!<br /><br />ORIGINAL REVIEW: Let me not waste your time and cut right to the chase: if you're thinking about buying your first Waterpik flosser--or wondering if it's time to upgrade your Ultra model--there's only one reason to consider the pricey WP-660 Aquarius: it looks nicer and more modern than the now dated design of the Ultra. So if appearance isn't important to you, stop reading right here and just go buy the cheaper Ultra, which (as I'll get to in a moment) is better in just about every other way.<br /><br />As it so happens, an attractive, modern design IS important to me, especially in an appliance that I'm going to look at all the time in my bathroom. But even in this regard I'd say the Aquarius is good but not great. It is definitely NOT an improvement in design that will have you looking past its ergonomic flaws vs. the Ultra.<br /><br />First, the on/off water flow switch is less user friendly in operation than the on/off button on the Ultra. Admittedly, there were issues with button failure at one time on the Ultra, but the replacement handle I received from Waterpik has been working for over a year now with no problems, so this seems to have been resolved.<br /><br />Second, getting the handle and hose &#34;re-holstered&#34; on the Aquarius is more finicky than it is on the Ultra--plus the hose never seems to sit in the unit as neatly.<br /><br />Third, the Aquarius weighs A FULL POUND less than the 2.5 pound Ultra, and you can't help but think that the weight was trimmed by using a lighter and less durable pump mechanism. Time will tell if that's really the case, but I've also found that the lightness of the Aquarius causes it to shift around too easily on my bathroom counter.<br /><br />Fourth, only two tips can be stored in the unit vs. all the tips being storable in the Ultra's lid. Waterpik has probably learned that its customers are fine with more limited tip storage, but again, this is no step forward.<br /><br />Fifth, the dual modes on the Aquarius--which could be seen as its only real advance vs. the single mode Ultra--are just a marketing gimmick. If you just want to massage your gums with the Ultra, simply dial down the water flow pressure and massage away. There's no need for a special mode to do this.<br /><br />Bottom line: water flossing is a mature technology, and there are few if any &#34;functional&#34; reasons to introduce a new model. So it's a shame that Waterpik didn't make more of an effort to at least achieve better ergonomics in a killer new design with the Aquarius. You can pay 20%+ more than the Ultra and get the somewhat nicer looking but ergonomically inferior Aquarius. Or you can just buy the Ultra and not bother to upgrade if you already own it. Both units will give you the same 5-star flossing ability. The Ultra will let you hang onto some extra cash while doing it.<br /><br />Thanks for taking the time to read my review and I hope you find it helpful in making a buying decision!n pay 20%+ more than the Ultra and get the somewhat nicer looking but ergonomically inferior Aquarius. Or you can just buy the Ultra and not bother to upgrade if you already own it. Both units will give you the same 5-star flossing ability. The Ultra will let you hang onto some extra cash while doing it.<br /><br />Thanks for taking the time to read my review and I hope you find it helpful in making a buying decision!
  1361. My teeth are close together and are hard to floss, especially in the back of my mouth. So, I don't like flossing. I use this machine once a day. I bought a second machine for my other house. I think this is better than flossing, and I use hydrogen peroxide in this machine (about three tablespoons in one full tank). Peroxide is inexpensive. My gums no longer have \\"bleeders,\\" and so far I haven't had any dental problems since I have been using this machine for two years. I used to have \\"bleeders.\\"
  1362. I love the 10 levels of power and all the tips that some with this. The whole family can use it with their own tip and settings.
  1363. very nice. my wife and i use it daily. get the job done, thanks.
  1364. The machine is alright but boy oh boy, not worth $80. Would never purchase another at this price. I'm disappointed.
  1365. Works very well and force level is fully adjustable. Appreciate the two modes; floss or massage.
  1366. I have an older Waterpik that is approximately 5 years old. It's done a good job but from the first time I used it, I felt like it was a little rough around the edges and very noisy. This new model is a considerable step up from that earlier one.<br /><br />For example, the handle has a spray-stop function. On the old one, it was a &#34;press and hold&#34; type of button and even when pressing your hardest, it still dribbled water and made a mess. The new one has a switch, and when it's switched off, the water is stopped completely. Very handy when you need to make an adjustment and don't need to turn it off entirely.<br /><br />It also includes a massage mode that would be good for those with gum problems by cycling from &#34;floss&#34; to &#34;massage&#34; with the button on the body.<br /><br />But most of all, the motor is much quieter, less an obnoxious grind and more of an aggressive purr. I'm not sure what has changed about how it uses water, but I am able to make it through my entire mouth and take my time where the old unit would have me rushing through to finish. Appears to be about the same amount of water, and they both do an equally good job, so the new model must be more efficient in some way.<br /><br />One minor downside to the new unit is nozzle storage. On the old one, it was a clamshell cover for the water cup that could contain a handful of different spray nozzles. In the new one, storage has been shifted to a small area between the water cup and main body, and it can only hold two nozzles. You then need to find a place to store the others if you think you might use them. I see them getting lost, but since I only work with the main spray nozzle and occasionally the flexible-tipped one, it's not a huge problem.

Not sure that it's a replacement for flossing, as there isn't any 'mechanical' contact, but it does blast any food particles from between your teeth and probably from in the gum line too. Can be a little sloppy to use, need to be leaned down close to the sink, as obviously the water from your mouth has to go somewhere. I'm over six feet, and if I don't pay attention to how far I'm bent over, water will end up running down my arm and drip off my elbow... and need to make sure you keep it aimed into your mouth. Seems like a simple thing, but it's easy to get it twisted and shoot water around the bathroom. Not an issue at all, and sometimes it's rather funny!

  1449. I've been using a much more expensive version of a water flosser for a few years, and it's starting to have problems.   1450. I had been using the Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser for a few years now. I had bought that one in 2011 when I got my braces put on, since it makes flossing soo much easier. I really thought it was one of the best inventions ever, so I was excited to give this Aquarius model a try.<br /><br />I really like the few improvements/differences on this Aquarius.<br /><br />I love that the lid is hinged and just lifts up and down. On the Ultra, the lid came totally off and it was cumbersome to place back on the water basin without one end falling in the water.<br /><br />I love the clear water basin, as opposed to the blue, It just looks nicer - nice and crystal clear.<br /><br />The body overall is slightly smaller and takes up a little less space on the counter.<br /><br />I like the look of the pressure control and the power buttons on the Aquarius better than the Ultra. The power button is a push button instead of a rocker, and it just seems more modern.<br /><br />The flow control on the handle sort of adds an extra step when you want to pause flossing and stop the water flow momentarily. On the Ultra, you just hold the button in and release when you're ready to start back up. In the Aquarius though it is actually a slide switch, so you actually turn the flow off and on. I like the button the Ultra a little better, but that may just be because I am used to it... using the button before was force of habit and I just kind if did it as needed without even thinking about it and I catch myself trying to just press that button and then have to stop and remember - new machine, different button. It is not a complaint though. It is still plenty easy to control the flow. It's just different than what I have been used to for the past several years.<br /><br />Plenty of different tips are included to address any need you may have. I actually only ever use the orthodontic tip because that is what felt like worked best for me with my braces.<br /><br />If you are debating whether a Waterpik is a good investment or not, I can tell you without a doubt that it is a GREAT investment, especially if you have braces. It is so much easier to maintain my braces and keep them and my teeth clean. I tend to get spaces in my teeth as they shift from the braces. The gum will actually separate from the tooth a little and food gets down in there and sort of compacts as I am eating. The Waterpik gets all of that pout for me. When I skip a day or two of using the Waterpik, I end up with sore gums and particles down in there. I really try to use it every day, but we all get a little lazy every now and then, right? Brushing alone just isn't enough though, of course, and the Waterpik is better than flossing with string, in my opinion.<br /><br />I can tell my teeth and gums are much healthier with using the Waterpik. I am a smoker, so I always had a little more builup, but using the flosser gets me much better reviews with the dental hygienist during my cleanings and checkups. My orthodontist has even said that my gums look better since I started using it. I feel good about that and I do not think I will ever stop using it.Waterpik is a good investment or not, I can tell you without a doubt that it is a GREAT investment, especially if you have braces. It is so much easier to maintain my braces and keep them and my teeth clean. I tend to get spaces in my teeth as they shift from the braces. The gum will actually separate from the tooth a little and food gets down in there and sort of compacts as I am eating. The Waterpik gets all of that pout for me. When I skip a day or two of using the Waterpik, I end up with sore gums and particles down in there. I really try to use it every day, but we all get a little lazy every now and then, right? Brushing alone just isn't enough though, of course, and the Waterpik is better than flossing with string, in my opinion.<br /><br />I can tell my teeth and gums are much healthier with using the Waterpik. I am a smoker, so I always had a little more builup, but using the flosser gets me much better reviews with the dental hygienist during my cleanings and checkups. My orthodontist has even said that my gums look better since I started using it. I feel good about that and I do not think I will ever stop using it.
  1451. I've always wanted a full-sized Waterpik but had to settle for smaller travel-sized versions because of non-existent counterspace. My current/previous dental irrigator is a travel Panasonic model that has only one type of tip and a a barely adjustable flow.<br /><br />Now that I have actual bathroom counter space, I can have and enjoy using a real oral irrigator. I love how there is a larger liquid capacity, different tips to clean more thoroughly and of course a handy little place to store all those tips in the lid.<br /><br />I am very happy with this Waterpik and would not hesitate to buy it at MSRP. I have no other experience with this brand's other products or other full-sized oral irrigators so cannot compare.
  1452. LOVE it; don't know how I've done without one all these years. Going to buy another one for my kids to share (it comes with multiple tips). Highly recommend! Now I can't wait for my next dental cleaning to see if my hygienist notices a difference.
  1453. I purchased a WP-100 back in 2008 that has served me very well over the years, but it was time for something new.<br /><br />The WP-660 has some nice new features, but takes away some that I'm going to miss from my older Waterpik.<br /><br />Among the new features is the mode switch which allows you to switch between massage and floss. One thing I like is the timer when you're in floss mode, but I don't care for the pause between cycles. It's kind of disconcerting and vaguely annoying. I'd prefer a plain beep instead. The head now has a ratcheting feature so it doesn't rotate so easily, but it's almost too strong and makes it hard to smoothly change the angle of the tip. The older model didn't have anything like that and at times seemed to move a bit too easily. So this one is a net improvement.<br /><br />The water tank at the top holds about 90 seconds worth of water which is great, but the top no longer allows a way of storing the collection of ends, which is a net loss.<br /><br />The most annoying change is the switch on the handle for stopping the flow of water. It's hard to manipulate and the design of the WP-100 is much easier to use.<br /><br />The WP-600 is a fine product and will likely serve you well over the years, but it would have been nice if they hadn't made it harder to use than the older WP-100
  1454. The Waterpik Water Flosser has a problem with it as the pick seems to come out more often than it stays in. For that reason, I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

  1456. [[VIDEOID:mo1GFD1DUOD3AR7]]When my dentist made me a bridge, she recommended to me to get a dental water jet system for cleaning - a Waterpik. Ordinary floss will no longer do the job as it cannot squeeze in between my new teeth. Not very familiar at that time about what a Waterpik is, I went to do my research and bought Waterpik Ultra Water Flosser. That was 3 years ago, now I have this new Waterpik Aquarius model.<br /><br />It occupies a small footprint. The jet has 10 power settings just like the older model. For my preference, I think 1 to 3 is weak, while 8 to 10 is too strong, so I stay right in the middle. I recommend to start by using the number 3 setting and adjust the knob as it suits you.<br /><br />There are a number of differences from the older model.<br />a) The Aquarius is more compact (although sacrificing a space for the accessories that used to be on the lid of the water reservoir - now you would need to find a place for the other tips. I put mine in the medicine cabinet). There is still a place for two extra tips; it is now located directly inside the water tank.<br />b) The addition of the gum massage button and LED.<br />c) Neutral colors provides better aesthetics.<br /><br />Water tank:<br />I filled the older water tank with water and then pour it to the water tank of the new Aquarius. It may look that the older model has more capacity but I found out they are just the same. The new tank has a smaller footprint but is taller.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- as with the older model, the water comes out of the tip if you forget to place it back on the hook. This sometimes happen with the kids and have a pool of water by the side of the sink or on the floor.<br /><br />What is missing?<br />- an ultrasonic vibration action that is present on my Interplak water dental jet system<br /><br />There are multiple attachments included. Changing between tips is very quick with the switch near the base for a quick release. Our favorite is the brush, unfortunately there is only one provided. The others are the regular classic flossers (3), a pick-pocket etc.<br /><br />With a dental bridge, I really will not be able to clean my teeth as thorough without a water jet. Not only it cleans the teeth, it also massage the gums. Of course if somebody in the family has a brace, this flosser is a must. It makes cleaning teeth more fun, specially for the kids Comparing the old and the new, I really don't have a favorite between the two. I am happy with either one.<br /><br />Tip: This is also great for cleaning small things thats that are impossible to reach. Good example are jewelries, sippy cups that has rubber parts,, etc.unfortunately there is only one provided. The others are the regular classic flossers (3), a pick-pocket etc.<br /><br />With a dental bridge, I really will not be able to clean my teeth as thorough without a water jet. Not only it cleans the teeth, it also massage the gums. Of course if somebody in the family has a brace, this flosser is a must. It makes cleaning teeth more fun, specially for the kids Comparing the old and the new, I really don't have a favorite between the two.   1457. This is not my first unit as I have been using them for forty years, curiously no new cavities. I go many years between filling replacements and have many 40 year old fillings.<br /><br />Unlike floss which drives food scraps into the gums, this blows them free. I blew a loose filling out once, so I only clean the sides of my teeth, I rarely use floss as it seems less effective.<br /><br />Mechanically:<br />1. This unit is a bit smaller ant the tank is easier to remove an reinstall - the tank must be dried after every use and all other water removed, tho unit is easier to remove as it doesn't stick on like the last design. We have calcium here which is a mess if allowed to dry.<br /><br />2, Pump reservoir seems smaller, warm water is pumped very fast - gone is the cold water &#34;gottcha&#34; of the previous units.<br /><br />3. The big deal - My last two units failed at the feed tube attachment to the handle - they made a stress relief tip on the handle at the break point - I am hoping for added life. Even if that does not happen, it makes storing the handle easier.<br /><br />4. I have tried other brands - not enough pressure to do the job. I like max pressure for a quick effective cleaning.<br /><br />5. I like the new touch controls.<br /><br />6. It is not at all obvious how they can ever improve this device.

  1512. I have used the Waterpik Ultra off-and-on for the last for the last four or five years. I like using it, but it seems to leave pools of water and it is a bit rough on my gums. The Waterpik Professional is very similar, but it easy to fill the reservoir and seems to be gentler on my gums.<br /><br />Notes-<br /><br /> - Try to use warm water - if you have sensitive teeth jet of cold water will really hurt.<br /><br /> - Includes multiple tips<br /> - One toothbrush water jet tip<br /> - Multiple standard tips<br /> - One tip for dental implants<br /> - One tip for braces<br /> - One Pik Pocket Tip for getting things between your teeth (only to be used on the lowest settings)<br /><br />- The tips can be swapped out very easily - even by younger children<br /><br />- Has a *Massage&#34; mode that shoots water in short bursts - but I am not fan.<br /><br />- It seems quieter than the Waterpik Ultra<br /><br />- Has a dial for water pressure settings - however even at the highest settings it doesn't seem to be too harsh on your gums.<br /><br />- Has a relatively long cord - at least four feet in length.<br /><br />- I do wish that it had a spot to hold all of the different attachments<br /><br />Final Verdict - I can't say that the WaterPik is substantial improvement over the Waterpik Ultra. It seems like the Waterpik Professional has a bit less power that its predecessor but it seems to be better designed and less likely to create pools of water.<br /><br />4 1/2 Stars
  1513. I've a huge fan of Waterpik. Several years ago, when my dentist told me I had the beginnings of periodontal disease, I rushed out and got a Waterpik. I've been religiously using it ever since, and I've beaten back the periodontal disease to the point where my dentist is impressed.<br /><br />My older Waterpik still works fine, but I was anxious to try this newer version. I frankly don't see what the improvements are that justify the higher cost.<br /><br />It's certainly prettier and more countertop worthy than my older standby. This one is taller, and the reservoir holds basically the same amount of water. This one is more glitzy with the LED stuff, and it makes the older model look quaint (but my view is that the more high tech stuff is, the more likely it is to break, and not be repairable.)<br /><br />The pressure settings feel about the same. I use the 8 setting on the older model; this one feels slightly more rough, but that could just be because it's so new.<br /><br />The Aquarius also has a gum massage thing going on (and I don't get the point of that, unless you wanna have pinky gums right before you go to the dentist.)<br /><br />Like I said, it works fine, but I don't see a vast amount of difference - except in the price. Of course, that could just be because we're in an inflation death spiral right now, so something that cost $40 a few years ago is now hitting $100. Overall, I don't think a few bells and whistles aren't worth double the price. But having said that, I do think anyone over the age of 30 (and certainly over 40) who wants to keep their teeth should make a Waterpik investment. It's one of the few things that really works to preserve your dental health.
  1514. This product exceeded my expectations. It's easy to use picks and the choices for the speed pump is excellent. I rate this 5 stars.

  1516. I'm an adult with braces (recently hit my 2 year mark) and have been using a Waterpik WP-100 a.k.a the Waterpik Ultra water flosser for the entire time I've had my braces. Like many folks who wear braces I found that using traditional cleansing techniques was both extremely time consuming and still left food particles in my braces. The Waterpik came recommended by my dentist and orthodontist. So I jumped at the opportunity to try the WP-660.<br /><br />--------------------<br />DESIGN:<br /><br />The WP-660 is very similar to my WP-100. Both feature a water reservoir, hose connected wand attachment with interchangeable cleaning heads. The major changes between the two seem to be color; the WP-660 is entirely white with a clear reservoir. The wand itself on the 660 has a toggle for controlling the water stream instead of a button that required depressing on my WP-100. The WP-660 also features a massaging feature (controlled on the main body instead of the wand) not present on the WP-100.<br /><br />Strangely the 660 is missing the tool compartment for storing all the different cleaning attachments that my WP-100 has. This was a compartment dome that fit inside the lid of the reservoir. Additionally there is not included storage case of any type. Meaning that if you switch between cleaning heads you're going to have to store your attachments somewhere of your own choosing or purchase a storage case.<br /><br />The WP-660 despite being a more expensive than my older 100-series also feels a bit more cheaply constructed. The plastics, particularly on the reservoir and lid feel cheaper and less durable.<br /><br />--------------------<br />USE:<br /><br />Functionally both the 660 and 100-series are very similar. I use the orthodontic-tip attachment most because of my braces and can easily withstand the stream from the WP-100 even at it's highest setting (10). That is not the case with the 660 and the water stream feels considerably stronger. In fact the manual for the 660 specifically points out not to use the highest water pressure setting for cleaning teeth. The massage feature is the other major change in the 660 and actually find it quite nice after thoroughly cleaning my teeth with the orthodontic-tip attachment. The massage feature essentially pulses water and helps promote gum health.<br /><br />Both the 660 and the 100 are loud but in different ways. I found the pitch of the WP-100 sounded more high-pitched, almost like a whine; and in the 660 it sounds lower, almost like a engine. Bottom-line is that neither is a quiet device though I found that I quickly adjusted to hearing it while cleaning my teeth in the same way that I adjusted to hearing my electric toothbrush.<br /><br />Similarly both devices are about the same size. Each takes up considerable real-estate on my bathroom counter but has become an indispensable part of my hygiene routine that it's worth the small inconvenience.<br /><br />--------------------<br />WHAT I LIKE:<br /><br />(+) The same cleaning action of my older WP-100 \\"Ultra\\" model with a little extra power and increased water pressure.<br /><br />(+) For a person with braces having a Waterpik is a must. This little device along with brushing and flossing will leave your mouth feeling clean. It's also perfect for quick rinses after eating foods when you don't have time for a full cleaning.<br /><br />(+) Neat, clean aesthetics. The device looks good, stores easily and is easy to clean.<br /><br />--------------------<br />WHAT I DON'T LIKE:<br /><br />(-) The WP-660 is, like its predecessor, extremely loud.<br /><br />(-) No included on-board storage for attachments.<br /><br />(-) Cheaper feeling plastics compared to the WP-100. Hopefully the cost savings that Waterpik implemented doesn't carry over to the internal components of 660.<br /><br />(-) Besides the massage feature and increased water pressure there's little reason to purchase the WP-660 over the WP-100.<br /><br />--------------------<br/>CONCLUSION:<br /><br />The WP-660 is a decent, well-featured water flosser. However, compared to the cheaper WP-100 Ultra there's little reason to spend the extra money. Recommended, but also check out the WP-100 to see if that fits your needs first!/>CONCLUSION:<br /><br />The WP-660 is a decent, well-featured water flosser. However, compared to the cheaper WP-100 Ultra there's little reason to spend the extra money. Recommended, but also check out the WP-100 to see if that fits your needs first!

  1549. This has completely changed my oral hygiene. My teeth have never felt so clean. It's easy to clean and I love all the different attachments.
  1550. I've been going through water piks way too quickly. I might have a winner here.<br /><br />First of all, this does not in any way, shape, or form replace flossing. I use POH floss (buypoh dot com). The water &#34;flosser&#34; is just for removing bits of food between crowded teeth. Rinsing, swishing, brushing (Sonicare), brush-picking, flossing don't do the trick for me. Gotta have a water pik. I disagree with the term &#34;water flosser.&#34; It's a water pik and does not floss.<br /><br />This is a nice unit with a 3-year warranty. The reservoir comes out easily and it grabs whatever is necessary when putting back on. No pushing it down to make it grab. Put it back, turn it on, and out comes the water. I like that the lid is not part of the reservoir. My last garbage water pik, I dropped the reservoir and the lid cracked off. The lid is part of the machine, so you cover it when you're using the unit and obviously when it's resting. And there are holes in the lid so that it seems to air out and no thought of getting maybe moldy. I shake the reservoir &#34;dry&#34; before putting it back and the holes in the lid seem to keep it &#34;clean&#34; or something like that.<br /><br />I'm using the unit at 8. The highest is 10. I use 10 when I fill the unit halfway with water and &#34;clean it out&#34; to expunge the baking soda that I've added. But in my mouth, I stick with 8. It's strong enough.<br /><br />I don't care about the on/off switch on the handle. I put the thing in my mouth and then turn the unit on. I also don't care about the 30 second markers. I use the entire reservoir going tooth to tooth first in the front and then in the back. I like that 30-second thing on the Sonicare so I'm sure to give each quadrant 30 seconds of brushing but don't see the benefit of that in the water pik.<br /><br />Hoping to get at least 3 years of service from this unit. I will check in in a year to report back!
  1551. excellent product, I fulfilled my expectations on time, packaging, quality and price. Excellent seller, highly recommend.<br /><br />best regards<br /><br />Guillermo Rey
  1552. It's like giving my teeth a Jacuzi ride - love this so much.

  1556. The slider switch on the handle to turn off the spray is very hard to slide. All this whilst leaning over the sink while spray is pulsing in my mouth.<br /><br />They have been making these things for over 40 years. There is no excuse for this inconvenient design.

  1581. SO MUCH BETTER THAN YOU LAST MODEL. THANK YOU FOR CHANGING IT. THE OLD ONES WOULD NOT WORK FOR VERY LONG BEFORE I HAD TO GET ANOTHER. THIS ONE LOOKS LIKE IT WILL HOLD UP BETTER. IF YOUHAVE TO CHOOSE FOR THIS AND THE OLD ONE I WOULD REMIND THIS ONE.

  1583. This thing is amazing!! My girlfriend, a dental hygienist, recommended I buy this when she realized that I am absolutely terrible at flossing. I hate it, I always lose my floss, I forget to do it, etc, etc. Since I've gotten my Waterpik, I've started using it every day and my gums and teeth are showing marked improvement.<br /><br />Also, it feels great! There are different strength settings, so you can adjust the flow of water to whatever is most comfortable for you.
  1584. Love being able to turn the water on and off while using the machine - much easier than the &#34;button&#34; they used to have on the older model that always seemed to get stuck.
  1585. My dentist recommended the Waterpik Water Flosser to get at hard to get places, like pockets. The flosser flosses, massages the gums, and has been very effective at cleaning pockets which are hard to get with a brush. I suspect that my pockets will be reduced by the time I see the dentist again. One of the big pluses is that your teeth and the gums feel the way the do after a cleaning and you can have this every day!
  1586. Works really well to help clean my gums and braces.
  1587. I like the massage feature. Missing a place to store the extra picks (brushes)

  1589. I really like this Waterpik and I use it after as many meals as possible--it really does a great job of releasing debris between teeth. Originally I started out on setting &#34;2&#34; and gradually increased it to &#34;7&#34; over the course of two weeks. The water reservoir is handy and lasts for several rinsing sessions.<br /><br />However, be aware that this device *cannot* fully replace manual flossing. I find that I still need to floss 2-3 times per week to get at some of the buildup between teeth, even with regular brushing.

  1598. It's been probably ten years or more since I've owned a water flosser; my last one was for when I had braces as a kid. I remember them being a true pain in the rear to operate, keep clean (along with my counters, mirrors, and sink). I admit I wasn't sure how I would enjoy another one from my less than fond memories of the last. I purchased this as I've had some gum issues and issues with food getting stuck in my back tooth and floss just wasn't cutting it (plus I tend to be lazy with flossing). I must say I really love this product though. I don't know if it's the strange obsession I have with seeing just how much crap is still left in my teeth after I brushed and then flossed or if it's just the convenience of this design and now being in the habit of using it, but I can't imagine how I went so long without one. My teeth and gums are more clean than they been in years and after three weeks of use, it's a night and day difference on the improvement of my gum health. I'm really still amazed about how well my gum health has improved. It comes with several different attachments (brush, flossers, one for braces or dental work) and I've only used the flosser. The water tank is large enough for me to do my entire mouth twice and I've never had to fill the tank twice. I've only made it to level six on the dial; it goes to ten but my goal is to remove particles not my gum line and six gets the job done for me. I have stopped flossing entirely and use this every night and my dentist said this actually works better than floss. Overall I highly recommend it.
  1599. No more crumbs in teeth.
  1600. Have been using this for a month. It does a good job flossing.
  1601. A lot of noise, the pump pressure jump during washing (to see if defective product ???), correct product
  1602. I've used this for a couple of weeks now. It appears to get stuff out of the teeth that regular flossing failed to get. Your mouth feels really good when you are finished. Wish I had purchased one of these a long time ago.
  1603. my dentist says it works
  1604. Looking at the reviews, there seems to be a consistent effort by what I take are some owners of the venerable Waterpik WP-100 Ultra to trash this new model and portrait it as inferior to the WP-100. I don't think this is the case, the WP-660 is an improvement over the WP-100 in many ways and I'll tell you why later. The funny thing is that when I bought my WP-100 about six years ago, there were some reviews from what I take were owners of the revered WP-60 Classic trashing the WP-100. I take some people prefer the old to the new and that's OK. But I think some reviewers are being unfair to the Aquarius<br /><br />I owned a WP-100 that lasted for little over six years, used almost every day by two people, those are a lot of days so the WP-100 is an outstanding product. I did have to replace the water reservoir once due to the cheap rubber valve mechanism -improved on the Aquarius as you will see- that failed after three years of use and started leaking. Also, the hook for the handle broke -also improved on the Aquarius- and it was very difficult if not impossible to hang the handle onto the Waterpik body, I had to makeshift a Velcro handle that looked terrible. Googleing around I was surprised to find that this is a common issue with the WP-100, some owners have replaced the entire unit just because of a broken handle as there is no spare part available from Waterpik. Boomer<br /><br />But other than those two issues, my Ultra worked flawlessly, I never had to replace the hose or the handle as some owners had to, the on-off switch never failed and it worked the same way it was when new until an accident damaged the power-cord and it stopped working. Given its state with the handle hook and its age, I thought about self-repairing it but then I decided it was time for a new unit. At first and reading all those pro-WP-100 anti-WP-660 reviews I was tempted to get another WP-100, but the price of the Aquarius was about the same as the Ultra so I decided to give it a try<br /><br />I'm glad I did. The first thing you notice with the Aquarius is its modern look and high quality materials, all white and clear, and gorgeous, a significant design improvement over the WP-100. It is also lighter, which some can argue is a good thing -like me- and some can argue it is a bad thing because it \\"feels\\" cheap, which is also a valid point. The important thing is that its weight doesn't compromise its operation in any way, it won't tip-off when used nor will slide or be unstable, it is just lighter. It might be due to the use of cheaper materials on the pump as some have argued here, or just lighter materials, an overall technological improvement rather than cheapening the unit off. I guess time will tell which one is more durable, or we will have to open both units and compare its guts to get a final answer. So, why is the Aquarius better than the WP-100, other than it looks?<br /><br />-The WP-660 is less noisy and runs smother than the WP-100, you notice this right away. This with no compromise to the water pressure, the pressure is steady, as or more powerful than the WP-100 but it runs better, it sounds less stressed. Same or better results with less noise.<br /><br />-The hook for the handle was replaced by a sturdier piece and a different design to hold the handle, which reduces the pressure on the piece. With the WP-100, it was very easy to push the handle all the way down the hook, either by accident or just because of its design, stressing the hook and eventually breaking it; there was nothing to stop the handle to slide all the way down. As said, mine broke. That was a poor design, fixed on the Aquarius; now you just put the handle on the holder, it cannot be pushed all the way down. Some have argued that makes it difficult to handle the hose, but I didn't find any issues, the hose juts hang there by simple gravity, it doesn't tangle or interfere with the unit in any way<br /><br />-The reservoir valve was replaced by a metal spring mechanism. This was a another design flaw of the WP-100, its reservoir valve consist of a rubber piece, very cheap in my opinion, which eventually gives up and start leaking after a few years. As said before, the only way to fix it is by buying an entire new reservoir as the little rubber piece is not available alone, which means not only paying way more but also a waste of resources. In contrast, the WP-660 has a stainless steel spring with a plastic cap, that appears way more durable and also a much better and higher quality solution. Only time will tell but it seems it will last longer than the one in the WP-100<br /><br />-The knob to graduate the pressure is easier to operate. The WP-100 has a hole to put both fingers in, on the Aquarius is a protruding knob, very easy to reach and to manipulate, way better I think, easier to find when in use if needed. And also more ergonomic<br /><br />-The Aquarius handle has an on-off switch that actually works. The WP-100 has that dreadful push button on the handle that you need to press constantly to stop the flow of water, doesn't stop it completely and also causes the Waterpik to make a noise like the pump is being damaged while the pressure is reverted. Not good at all, it was a poor solution at best, a useless feature at worst, it just didn't work. On the WP-660, there is an actual on-off button; in fact the correct way to operate this new Waterpik is to turn it on the base first, then turn it on via the handle when you already have the tip inside your mouth ready to go, the water doesn't come out unless you turn the handle on. This is much better than having to reach the switch on the base unit with the tip in your mouth or having to hold into the appalling pressure cutting button on the handle and then release it. All this while water was still coming out of the tip as the button didn't cut the water flow completely.<br /><br />-The pace timer. This feature is non-existent on the Ultra, and I realized it is very helpful. I use the Waterpik first on the upper section of the mouth, outside-inside and then move to the lower section, in-out and I'm done. At a pressure level of 8, the water in the reservoir, at full capacity, should last little less than 90 seconds. The Aquarius will give you a very short flow pause at 30 seconds of use and another at 60 seconds, this is good to pace your cleaning as it should take about 30 seconds to clean each part of the mouth, up and down, and then you have an extra 20 seconds to touch-up. This avoids you having to be periodically peaking over to the reservoir to see how much water is left and instead allow you to concentrate on the cleaning and doing the job properly<br /><br />-The reservoir cover is now part of the unit. If you are like my mother in law that misplaces everything - sorry mom, I still love you-, chances are you have misplaced the reservoir cover of the WP-100 (as my mother in law did). This cover also contains the tips so it can be kind of an inconvenience to lose it. On the WP-660, the cover is attached with a hinge mechanism to the body of the Waterpik, no way to lose it. The tips are now stored on the unit itself, behind the reservoir<br /><br />The rest is about the same as the WP-100, it comes with a bunch of tips from which you will probably only use the classic jet, and a 3 years warranty. It also includes a gum massaging mode which is pointless as you can achieve the same results by regulating the pressure knob. One disadvantage to the WP-100 is that you can only store two tips on the unit and not four, but again if you are like me that use only one, this is not an issue. But it might be for some users, if you have braces for example or like to regularly use the one designed for root canal maintenance (the Pik Pocket). One thing that was bad on the WP-100 and remain as bad on the WP-660 is cable management, there is no place to wrap the cable or at least a Velcro band included to deal with the cable, this lack of cablemanagement is in part responsible for the damage to my WP-100 power cord, the cord is just hanging there. A needed improvement for the next design, please take note Waterpik<br /><br />Overall, I see no disadvantages when compared with the WP-100 and instead see many advantages. Until the unit has more years in the market, speculating about its durability without real facts is pointless at this time, so far the Aquarius works the same or better than the Ultra so it's higher price is justifiable. And you can even get a good deal and get it at the same price or a little cheaper than the Ultra, which is a real bargainul. I use the Waterpik first on the upper section of the mouth, outside-inside and then move to the lower section, in-out and I'm done. At a pressure level of 8, the water in the reservoir, at full capacity, should last little less than 90 seconds. The Aquarius will give you a very short flow pause at 30 seconds of use and another at 60 seconds, this is good to pace your cleaning as it should take about 30 seconds to clean each part of the mouth, up and down, and then you have an extra 20 seconds to touch-up. This avoids you having to be periodically peaking over to the reservoir to see how much water is left and instead allow you to concentrate on the cleaning and doing the job properly<br /><br />-The reservoir cover is now part of the unit. If you are like my mother in law that misplaces everything - sorry mom, I still love you-, chances are you have misplaced the reservoir cover of the WP-100 (as my mother in law did). This cover also contains the tips so it can be kind of an inconvenience to lose it. On the WP-660, the cover is attached with a hinge mechanism to the body of the Waterpik, no way to lose it. The tips are now stored on the unit itself, behind the reservoir<br /><br />The rest is about the same as the WP-100, it comes with a bunch of tips from which you will probably only use the classic jet, and a 3 years warranty. It also includes a gum massaging mode which is pointless as you can achieve the same results by regulating the pressure knob. One disadvantage to the WP-100 is that you can only store two tips on the unit and not four, but again if you are like me that use only one, this is not an issue. But it might be for some users, if you have braces for example or like to regularly use the one designed for root canal maintenance (the Pik Pocket). One thing that was bad on the WP-100 and remain as bad on the WP-660 is cable management, there is no place to wrap the cable or at least a Velcro band included to deal with the cable, this lack of cablemanagement is in part responsible for the damage to my WP-100 power cord, the cord is just hanging there. A needed improvement for the next design, please take note Waterpik<br /><br />Overall, I see no disadvantages when compared with the WP-100 and instead see many advantages. Until the unit has more years in the market, speculating about its durability without real facts is pointless at this time, so far the Aquarius works the same or better than the Ultra so it's higher price is justifiable. And you can even get a good deal and get it at the same price or a little cheaper than the Ultra, which is a real bargain
  1605. I have not use it yet,but i feel it ok.
  1606. The Water Pik does a fantastic job of cleaning/flossing your teeth.
  1607. Could not ask for anything to work any better
  1608. It's great, leaves your mouth feeling clean.

  1610. His dentist recommended this. I was hesitant because the older Waterpiks were not that easy and they were sloppy to use. But my husband loves using this one. Not messy at all. Does the job nicely.........We use a toothbrush sanitizer to sanitize the flosser.<br /><br />Beware if you have a joint replacement or heart condition, especially if you're required to take antibiotics before any dental procedure, including a cleaning. The loosened bacteria can cause a heart attack or an infection in the prosthesis. Waterpik makes this clear in the brochure that comes with the unit.<br /><br />My recommendation is to call your cardiologist and/or orthopedic doctor before purchasing.

But, that is true with a teenage girl without this contraption!
  1624. I love this water flosser. It is small and compact to fit nicely in my small bathroom. I call it my teeth and gum tool. When I first purchased it, I did so because I have implants and bridges, and I hated the way the threader worked, and really could not make it work. Also, when I got it, I first brushed my teeth, and then I used my little brush pics. After that, I used the pic for flossing implants and bridges, and was amazed how much gunk came out from between my teeth. Honestly, it looked like tiny bugs were being released from between my teeth and that was after the usual brush and floss. I wish I had started using this product years ago, and I might still have my real teeth in the back instead of implants. I even love cleaning my teeth without having to put my hands in my mouth trying to grab that floss thread.
  1625. This just squeaked by with a four. The on off switch on the hand held handle is sticky and obsolete. Just fill up the tank, and put the pic, or whatever in your mouth, and turn it on from unit.<br /><br />It is not a powerful jet, but feels good and does the job. Gentle on the gums.
  1626. The pulsing action of the jet is a less than satisfactory feeling for me. I liked the steady stream of my old water flosser, but unfortunately that stream turned into more of a trickle (much like those of us with problems in certain regions down-under) so I got this little beauty to replace the old one.<br /><br />Love the convenience of the on/off switch on the actual flosser. The pulsing action of the jet makes the high setting too hard on my gums, so I have to turn it down to an 8, but then it seems less effective at getting stuff out from between the ole chompers (Yes. Teeth.) But with a little bit of luck, time, and regular dental floss we are able to get most of the food bits.   1636. This has to be the most wonderful invention ever devised.   1640. I purchased this to replace a 2 year old WP-100. The WP-100 felt underpowered from date of purchase and over time seemed to lose pressure.   1649. Let me not waste your time and cut right to the chase: if you're thinking about buying your first Waterpik flosser--or wondering if it's time to upgrade your Ultra model--there's only one reason to consider the pricey WP-660 Aquarius: it looks nicer and more modern than the now dated design of the Ultra. So if appearance isn't important to you, stop reading right here and just go buy the cheaper Ultra, which (as I'll get to in a moment) is better in just about every other way.<br /><br />As it so happens, an attractive, modern design IS important to me, especially in an appliance that I'm going to look at all the time in my bathroom. But even in this regard I'd say the Aquarius is good but not great. It is definitely NOT an improvement in design that will have you looking past its ergonomic flaws vs. the Ultra.

  1657. I like it but don't know why yet. I wanted to pick one of these up because I was always curious as to how it worked, and if I could finally get rid of the awful sensation of flossing. The first thing to note is that this does blast a high powered concentration of water at your gum lines, so if you have a mirror in front of you like I do expect to do some cleaning. The instructions were a bit vague so I'll describe the process of water flossing here.<br /><br />First you fill the reservoir with luke warm water, adjust the water pressure dial for intensity, and somehow try and get the thing in your mouth without spraying water everywhere. The actual usage is to align it between your teeth pointed toward the gumline. This will blow out any food stuck between your teeth and loosen up pockets of tarter. I usually do a once over on the outside of the teeth and then once on the inside. Time-wise this will add a few minutes to your daily dental routine.<br /><br />The control and mechanism of use are easy enough to figure out, and the supplied variety of tips gives a good overall value. The unit itself is slightly bulky but not obtrusive, and it seems to fit the ambiance of my Sonicare section.<br /><br />I would highly recommend this if your not the greatest flosser in the world, or just don't like the feeling of flossing, and if your willing to do a bit of cleanup afterward.
  1658. Works great. First time user of water floss, surprised how easy and better than thread way.
  1659. Used every day and she loves the results
  1660. Does what it is supposed to do. My teeth feel clean and refreshed after using it
  1661. I spend a considerable amount of time researching products before purchasing them, and a new Waterpik was no exception. I read through the pros and cons for this unit, and decided that I could purchase this confidently. The package was hassle free, and set up was a breeze. The unit is very intuitive to use, the manual is basically not needed. I love how little counter space the unit takes up, and the modern design isn't an eyesore on the bathroom counter. The top closes over the water reservoir, so no dust collects in their. All the pieces snap together nicely, and everything feels sturdy and durable. The setting for water pressure is responsive, and I LOVE how the water flow pulses, reminding you to move on to the next area in your mouth. I like how the cord on the unit coils up back into a built in pocket on the unit. Really, this is a very good device and one I could recomend without reservation. If there's one complaint I do have, it would be that the device doesn't have the space to hold all the different little nozels that it comes with and can only hold two. They are tucked under the lid, thereby helping to avoid dust contamination. I guess you sacrafice the storage space for the svelt design of the unit. It's not a huge deal, I have drawers and cupboards in my bathroom and just have the extra tips in a container in one of the drawers.<br /><br />Pros- great compact modern design<br /> durable feel, not cheap feeling<br /> lid closes keeping water reservoir and tips free from dust/contamination<br /> intuitive user experience<br /> responsive settings<br /><br />Cons- lack of space to hold extra tips<br /><br />If you're looking for a good oral irrigator, I would highly recomend considering the Waterpik Aquarius

  1728. The Aquarius makes significant but seemingly minor improvements over the WP-100. I bought it to replace a decade-old WP-100 that died on me.<br /><br />-Connector in tank is made out of plastic. The connector in the WP-100 was made of rubber, and over time it started to peel and fall apart.<br />-On-off switch on handle. The WP-100 had a pause button that was useless because it was constantly getting stuck. This switch actually works.<br />-Flip lid means no more accessories falling into the tank, which always happened to me on the WP-100.<br />-It looks a lot nicer.<br /><br />I do wish this unit would be shorter and fold up like the old-school Waterpiks. The Aquarius is much lighter than the WP-100, and if they had made it more portable, I'd give it 5 stars. There are several usage modes, but honestly, I find them kind of useless and I never actually bother with them.

  1753. Functions as expected and just fine. The only reason that I did not rate it with five stars is that the location where the tips are stored can only be accessed with the water reservoir removed.<br /><br />I have read in other reviews where others have had problems with spraying water all over their bathroom mirrors, their faces, etc. I do not have that problem nor did my wife. Quite simply, those with the spraying problems should insert the tip fully into their mouths BEFORE turning the water on the handle. Secondly, bend over the sink and keep their mouths nearly closed, opened no more than necessary to permit the water to flow into the sink! Simple, huh!<br /><br />Delivery from Amazon was as promised. Packaging was as it should be; protected and in a box appropriate for the item being shipped.<br /><br />Montana Bob

  1808. This is *such* a great tool. I feel like it brings a whole new level of cleanliness to my mouth (I'm pretty much addicted to using it 1 or 2 times a day now).<br /><br />I had been using a nice Sonicare electronic toothbrush & flossing, but my dentist recommended I get a water pick to help out just a little more along the edge of my gums. I couple of years ago I had bought a cordless Waterpik Waterflosser ... but it was so weak that I didn't feel like it was making a difference, and so cumbersome to use that I just really never wanted to use it (I probably used it 12 times in a couple of years).<br /><br />Based on online reviews, I decided to give this Waterpik WP-660 a try. And was I impressed! I only have to fill the tank 1 time to do my entire mouth, I can hold the wand in any position/angle I want, and I can dial-up as much pressure as I would want. As an initial test, I turned the pressure on 6 (out of 10), and ran the water jet around the edge of the metal hole/plug in the sink - it quickly blew out all the grime that brushes & cleanser hadn't been able to get out! (if it could do that to sink grime, I knew it could easily blast out any food & plaque that might be around my teeth).<br /><br />I've been using it for a week now (using the standard tip, and pressure from 4-8), and my teeth (and whole mouth) just 'feel' cleaner than they've ever been. It's so convenient to use, and I feel like it's actually doing something, that I am actually eager to use it every day (as opposed to the cordless one), and sometimes use it an extra time after a meal or snack just to get the food remnants out from between my teeth.

  1814. I've had dental surgery for gum problems and the periodontist office recommended getting a Waterpik that has the tip designed for getting into pockets in the gums. I first bought the standard model you see everywhere at drug stores, but returned it - too big and bulky for my small sink, very noisy, no cover on the water tank, and too much water flow for me to even find the pockets. I then ordered this model and really like it. It doesn't take up as much room on the counter, it has a cover over the water, and comes with several different tips. They include the one designed for getting into pockets, one with a toothbrush head, one designed for braces, and one with bristles that is also more effective for pockets and removing plaque. It also has two settings, floss or massage, and much better controls for the water flow you want. I like it so much that I just ordered one for my son. This is more effective than my Sonicare air/water flosser to get into those pockets.

  1818. So far, so good. I used to use the Phillips airfloss, but after breaking two of them, I think I'll stick with the Waterpik going forward unless I'm traveling. They both seem to offer plenty of pressure, but the Waterpik holds so much more water that it's way quicker and easier. I usually had to go through two refills when using the airfloss, but with this I just fill it up and turn it on until it's all gone. I can usually do all my teeth twice. It's obviously not as portable and requires some counter space, but overall I just think it's better. It comes with a few different nozzles and settings, but I tend to just use the standard nozzle and max pressure.<br /><br />Don't get rid of your airfloss though, as this really isn't travel friendly.

I would recommend for teens or adults, but it is a bit messy for my 7 year old.
